docTitle.titlePart: JACK STRAW JACK STRAW A FARCE In Three Acts

titlePage.docImprint: Copyright ,LondonWilliam Heinemann ,1912This play was produced at the Vaudeville Theatre on March 26 ,1908, with the following cast : JACK STRAW CHARLES HAWTREY COUNT VON BREMER H. R. HIGNETT MARQUESS OF SERLO LOUIS GOODRICH REV . LEWIS ABBOTT CHARLES TROODE AMBROSE HOLLAND EDMUND MAURICE MR. PARKER-JENNINGS ROBERT WHITE , JUNR VINCENT PARKER-JENNINGS PERCY R. GOODYER HEAD WAITER VINCENT ERNE SERVANT NORMAN WRIGHTON LADY WANLEY VANE FEATHERSTONE ETHEL PARKER-JENNINGS DAGMAR WIEHE ROSIE ABBOTT MONA HARRISON MRS. WITHERS JOY CHATWYN MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS LOTTIE VENNE

castItem.role: Waiters at the Grand Babylon Hotel and Footmen at Taverner

div.head: ACT I — The Lounge of the Grand Babylon Hotel

stage.stage: ACTS II and III — The Parker-Jennings ’ place in Cheshire

The Performing Rights of this play are fully protected , and permission to perform it , whether by Amateurs or Professionals , must be obtained in advance from the author ’ s Sole Agent , R. Golding Bright , 20 Green Street , Leicester Square , London , W. C ., from whom all particulars can be obtained .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: THE FIRST ACT SCENE : The lounge and winter garden of the Grand Babylon Hotel . There are palms and flowers in profusion , and numbers of little tables , surrounded each by two or three chairs . Several people are seated , drinking coffee and liqueurs . At the back a flight of steps leads to the restaurant , separated from the winter garden by a leaded glass partition and swinging doors . In the restaurant a band is playing . Two or three waiters in uniform are standing about or serving customers . AMBROSE HOLLAND and LADY WANLEY come out from the restaurant . He is a well-dressed , elegant man of five and thirty . She is a handsome widow of uncertain age .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Pausing at the foot of the steps .Where shall we sit ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Let us choose a retired corner where we can gossip in peace .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Nonsense ! I didn ’ t come to the Grand Babylon in order to blush unseen . I caught sight of a number of people during luncheon , who I ’ m quite determined shall catch sight of me now .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I was sufficiently gallant to have eyes for you only .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Pointing to a table .Shall we sit there ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: D ’ you mind sitting on the other side ? The waiter ’ s rather a pal of mine .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Sitting down .What queer friends you have .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Waiter .

sp.speaker: A WAITER
sp.p: Coming forward .Your waiter will be here in one minute , sir .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: To LADY WANLEY .You see , I ’ ve knocked about in so many places that I have friends in every city in the world and every rank in life .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I suppose you saw the Parker-Jennings ? They were sitting three tables from us .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I did .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Do you know that she cut me dead when I came in ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I ’ ve long told you that Mrs. Parker-Jennings is growing exclusive .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: But , my dear Ambrose , that she should have the impudence to cut me ....

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Smiling .I respect her for it .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I ’ m much obliged to you .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I don ’ t think it does much credit to her heart , but it certainly does to her understanding . She has discovered that a title nowadays is not nearly such a good passport to the world of fashion as she thought it was . She knows you ’ re as poor as a church mouse , and she ’ s realised that in Society the poor are quite rightly hated and despised by all who know them .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Yes , but remember the circumstances . Five years ago the Parker-Jennings didn ’ t know a soul in the world . They ’ d lived in Brixton all their lives .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: It has been whispered to me that in those days they were known as Mr. and Mrs. Bob Jennings — not nearly so smart , is it ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: He used to go to the City every morning with a black bag in one hand and an umbrella in the other .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I wish that confounded waiter would come .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: One day an uncle in the North , from whom they vaguely had expectations , died suddenly and left them nearly two millions .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Some people are so lucky in the way they choose their uncles .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: He was a hardware manufacturer , and no one dreamt that he had a tenth part of that fortune . I came across them in Switzerland and found they were looking for a house .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: So , with a burst of hospitality , you asked them down to Taverner , and they took it for twenty-one years .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I introduced them to every one in the county . I gave little parties so that they might meet people . And now , if you please , the woman cuts me .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Dryly .You have left out an essential detail in the account of your relations with these good folk .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Have I ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Smiling .You have omitted to mention that when they took Taverner they agreed to pay an exorbitant rent .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: They could well afford it . Besides , it was a historic place . It was worth whatever I could get for it .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Parker-Jennings may be very vulgar , but he ’ s as shrewd a man as you ’ d find anywhere between Park Lane and Jerusalem .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I haven ’ t the least idea what you ’ re talking about .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Haven ’ t you ? Well , then , I venture to suggest that if Mr. Parker-Jennings gave you such an enormous rent for Taverner , it was on a certain understanding . He was wise enough to find out that people can live in Cheshire all their lives and never know a soul . I don ’ t suppose he put it in the agreement between you , but unless I am very much mistaken he took your place only on the condition that you should get every one to call .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: After a brief pause .I was crippled with mortgages , and I had to send my boys to Eton .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Good heavens , I ’ m not blaming you . I only wish to point out that if you introduced Mrs. Jennings to your friends , it was a matter of business rather than of sentiment .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: With a little laugh .I suppose you think it ’ s very natural that she should wish to kick away the ladder by which she climbed .

div.stage: A WAITER comes up to HOLLAND .

sp.speaker: WAITER
sp.p: JACK STRAWYes , sir .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Two coffees and two Benedictines . But you ’ re not my usual waiter . Where ’ s Pierre ?

sp.speaker: WAITER
sp.p: Blandly .He ’ s attending the funeral of an elderly female relative , sir .

div.stage: HOLLAND looks up quickly , and then stares in a puzzled way .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I seem to know your face . Have I seen you anywhere ?

sp.speaker: WAITER
sp.p: With a smile .Mr. Ambrose Holland , I think .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Jack Straw ! What on earth are you doing here ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: My dear fellow , it is possible to be no less of a philosopher in the uniform of a waiter at the Grand Babylon Hotel than in the gown of a professor at the University of Oxford .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Laughing .It ’ s really very odd that waiters should address you as my dear fellow .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: What an extraordinary encounter !

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Please tell me who your friend is .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I haven ’ t the ghost of an idea .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: My dear Ambrose .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I first met him in the States . I was in considerable financial difficulties in those days — it ’ s three or four years ago now — and I got a small part in a travelling company . Jack Straw was a member of it , and we became great friends .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Is that his name ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: So he assures me .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: It ’ s very improbable , isn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Very . I believe Jack Straw was a highwayman , or something like that , and he ’ s given his name to a public-house in Hampstead .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: He must be an extraordinary man .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: He is . I don ’ t know whether I admire most his self-assurance or his resourcefulness . I spent with him the last two years before my ship came home . We had some pretty rough times together , but he was a pillar of strength . Difficulties seemed to arise only that he might surmount them .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: He sounds quite splendid .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: The worst of living with him was that you had no breathing-time . He ’ s a man with an uncontrollable love of adventure . Prosperity bores him to death , and time after time , when we ’ d managed to get out of rough water into smooth , he ’ d throw up everything for some wild goose chase .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: But who are his people ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Heaven only knows . I know he isn ’ t English , though he speaks it wonderfully .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Is he by way of being a gentleman ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I can only tell you that he ’ s thoroughly at home in whatever society he finds himself .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I daresay that ’ s not a bad definition of a gentleman .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: He ’ s sailed before the mast , been a bar-tender in New York , and an engine-driver on the Canadian Pacific . He ’ s been a miner up in the Klondyke , and he ’ s worked on a ranch in Texas . And if he ’ s a waiter now , I daresay he ’ ll be an organ-grinder next week , and a company-promoter the week after . I ’ ve seen half a dozen fortunes within his grasp , and he ’ s let them all slip through his fingers from sheer indifference to money .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Here he is with the coffee .

div.stage: JACK STRAW comes in with coffee and liqueurs .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I should be overwhelmed with confusion at allowing you to wait on me , if I did not feel certain that it appeals enormously to your sense of humour .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It has occurred to me that you will feel a natural hesitation about giving me a tip . I may as well tell you at once that I shall feel none about taking it .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: It ’ s thoughtful of you to warn me . How much do I owe you ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Two shillings the coffee and three shillings the liqueur . The prices seem exorbitant to me , but I suppose people must expect to pay for the privilege of letting their friends see them at the best hotel in Europe .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Putting down a coin .Don ’ t bother about the change .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Half a sovereign . My dear fellow , when you offer me a tip of five shillings you are presuming unwarrantably on our former acquaintance .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Helplessly .I ’ m sure I beg your pardon .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I will keep one shilling as an adequate remuneration for my services and return you four .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I am overpowered by your condescension .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: To LADY WANLEY , who has put a cigarette in her mouth .Light , madam ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I should like to ask you to sit down .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It would be eminently improper . Besides , I have other tables to attend to . But I shall be delighted to dine with you to-night if you have no other engagement .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: It ’ s very kind of you . But will not your duties here detain you ?... Mr . Straw — Lady Wanley .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Bowing .How do you do . I ’ m only engaged here for the afternoon . Your ladyship is aware that the lower orders make a speciality in the decease of elderly female relatives .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I have often been impressed by the piety with which they bury their maternal grandmothers .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It appears that Pierre , an old acquaintance of mine , wished to attend the funeral of a widowed aunt , the relic of an egg importer in Soho , and a highly respectable person .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I can well imagine that nothing could be more respectable than to import eggs to Soho .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: The head-waiter , who is an excellent fellow , with female relatives of his own , promised to overlook his absence if he could find a substitute . Pierre , like myself , is a person of somewhat striking physique and could find no one able to wear his clothes . He confided his distress to me , and I , knowing that his uniform would fit me like a glove offered , at once to step into the — breach .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I am relieved to hear that your appearance in this capacity is not due to embarrassed circumstances .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I deplore the hastiness of your reasoning . My circumstances are excessively embarrassed . Excuse me , I see some people who are proposing to sit at one of my tables .

div.stage: Meanwhile people have been coming down from the restaurant and sitting at the various tables . Waiters have been handing them coffee . HORTON WITHERS and MRS. WITHERS come down , accompanied by the REV . LEWIS ABBOTT and MRS. ABBOTT ( ROSIE ) . JACK STRAW leaves HOLLAND and LADY WANLEY to attend to some people .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: There are the Withers . Why , they ’ ve got Rosie with them and her husband .

div.stage: She gets up and goes towards the WITHERS , who are honest , simple people , not distinguished , but good-natured and kindly . LEWIS ABBOTT is a nice-looking , frank young parson . ROSIE is very pretty and fragile . She is simply dressed .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Smiling to ROSIE .My dear , what are you doing in this sink of iniquity ? I am surprised to see you . And Lewis !

div.stage: She shakes hands , evidently delighted to see them .

sp.speaker: WITHERS
sp.p: We ’ ve brought them up to London for a little jaunt .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Won ’ t you all sit at our table ? There ’ s plenty of room .

sp.speaker: WITHERS
sp.p: That ’ s very kind of you .To his wife .Fanny , you know Mr. Holland .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: Yes , of course I do . How do you do , Lady Wanley .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: How do you do ? Now you two young things must sit one on each side of me , and you must tell me all about Taverner .

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: Oh , we ’ re so happy there , and everything ’ s beautiful , and we just love the house .

lg.l: I don ’ t believe you know Mr. Holland . Ambrose , this is Rosie , Jasper
Neville ’ s daughter . You knew him well , didn ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Of course I did .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: And this is Rosie ’ s husband and my new Vicar at Taverner .

sp.speaker: ABBOTT
sp.p: It makes me feel awfully grand .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I adore them both , so you must like them . These dear things were waiting to be married . Lewis was a curate in some dreadfully shabby suburb , and he ’ s a saint .

sp.speaker: ABBOTT
sp.p: I wish you wouldn ’ t say such absurd things about me .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Nonsense . He ’ s a saint , but quite a modern nice sort of saint , who plays cricket and doesn ’ t wear a hair shirt . And of course he couldn ’ t marry Rosie , who hadn ’ t a penny to bless herself with , but Providence came to the rescue and carried off our old Vicar with influenza .

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: What dreadful things you say , Lady Wanley !

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: And the living ’ s in my gift , so I gave it to them , and there they are .

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: You have been nice to us .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: My dears , you ’ re the only really good people I ’ ve ever known in my life . I used to think my boys were till they went to Eton , and now I know they ’ re devils .

sp.speaker: WITHERS
sp.p: We ’ re all under a debt of gratitude to you , Lady Wanley . Every one worships them in the parish .

sp.speaker: ABBOTT
sp.p: Every one ’ s been very jolly , and they all try to make things easy for us .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: You know , they will work so hard , we could hardly persuade them to come up to London for two or three days .

sp.speaker: WITHERS
sp.p: I daresay you ’ ve heard that we ’ ve taken a little place near Taverner .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Lady Wanley was telling me at luncheon .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: To ROSIE .And are you enjoying yourself in London , darling ?

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: Enthusiastically .Oh , it ’ s simply splendid . You don ’ t know what a treat it is to us to come to the Grand Babylon . It makes us feel so smart . And to-night we ’ re going to the Gaiety .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: To WITHERS .It ’ s very nice of you to be so good to these young people .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: It ’ s a pleasure to us to see how they enjoy everything .

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: D ’ you know the Parker-Jennings are here ? Isn ’ t it nice ? They will be surprised when they see us , won ’ t they , Lewis ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: With a little sniff .I see Maria Jennings has got a lord with her .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Serlo , isn ’ t it ? I thought I saw him .

sp.speaker: WITHERS
sp.p: I suppose you know they ’ re trying to hook him for Ethel ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Good heavens !

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: With a shrug of the shoulders .As long as he ’ s a Marquess , and he ’ s that all right , Maria Jennings don ’ t mind the rest .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I hope Ethel will refuse to have anything to do with him .

lg.l: She ’ s a dear , isn ’ t she ? I ’ m so fond of her , and she ’ s simply devoted to
Lewis .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: My dear , do you never say anything against any one ?

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: With a laugh .Seldom . Everybody ’ s so nice .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: It must make conversation very difficult . But Ethel is a charming girl , and I shouldn ’ t like her to fall into the hands of that disgraceful young rip .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: She ’ s the only one of the family who hasn ’ t had her head turned by all the money .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Of course you knew Mrs. Jennings before she was the exalted person she is now .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: Bless you , I ’ ve known her all my life . We went to the Brixton High School together , and I was a bridesmaid at her wedding . Why , we used to be popping in and out of one another ’ s houses all day long .

sp.speaker: WITHERS
sp.p: And now , if you please , she ’ ll hardly look at us .

sp.speaker: ABBOTT
sp.p: I ’ m afraid people don ’ t much like her at Taverner , but she ’ s done everything she could for us , and they ’ re awfully generous .

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: I don ’ t care what anybody says about her , she ’ s been perfectly sweet to me . She told me that I might come to the Hall whenever I wanted to , and I ’ m always dropping in to lunch there .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Oh well , if they ’ re nice to you , I forgive them . Mrs. Jennings can cut me till she ’ s blue in the face .

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: Oh look , there ’ s the Count .

div.stage: A distinguished-looking old man comes out of the restaurant and walks slowly down the steps .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: It ’ s Adrian von Bremer . How on earth d ’ you know him ?

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: I don ’ t , but he ’ s rented a place in Cheshire , and he came to church once .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: It ’ s the Pomeranian Ambassador , you know .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: I know him well by sight .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I wish he ’ d come and talk to us . I should like to introduce Lewis to him .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: He ’ s as blind as a bat . I don ’ t suppose he ’ ll see us .

div.stage: Meanwhile VON BREMER has reflectively put an eyeglass in his eye , and looks round as he walks out . He catches sight of LADY WANLEY , and smiling , comes up to her .

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: How do you do .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: You look as if you were just going .

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: I am . I had my coffee in the restaurant .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: What is the news in Pomerania ?

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: None except that our Emperor is growing old . All these domestic troubles of his are breaking him down .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Poor old thing .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I suppose nothing has been heard of the Archduke Sebastian ?

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: Nothing . We ’ ve given up the search .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: To LADY WANLEY .You remember that affair , don ’ t you ? There was some quarrel in the domestic circle , and the Archduke Sebastian suddenly disappeared — four years ago , now , isn ’ t it ?— and hasn ’ t been heard of since . He simply vanished into thin air .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: But how do you know he ’ s alive ?

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: Every Christmas the Emperor receives a letter from him , sent from different parts of the world , saying he ’ s well and happy .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: It ’ s really very romantic . I wonder what on earth he ’ s doing .

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: Heaven only knows .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Tell me , how is that nice young attaché of yours that I met at luncheon the other day .

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: The nice young attaché has come to a bad end . I ’ ve had to send him back to Pomerania .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: The story is rather entertaining . There ’ s an American woman here who has a passion for titles , and it occurred to my attaché one day to introduce his valet to her as Count So-and-So . Of course she was full of attentions and immediately asked the valet to dinner . Presently the story came to my ears . I really couldn ’ t have my attachés playing practical jokes of that sort , and so I sent him home .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Poor boy , he was so nice .

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: Good-bye .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Oh , may I introduce Mr. Abbott to you . He ’ s your new Vicar at Taverner . And this is Mrs. Abbott . You must be very nice to her .

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: I ’ m delighted to meet you . I ’ ve heard wonderful stories of your good works in the parish .

sp.speaker: ABBOTT
sp.p: It ’ s very kind of you to say so .

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: To ROSIE .If you will allow me I should like to call on you when I come down to Cheshire .

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: I shall be so pleased to see you .

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: He bows and goes out .

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: Wasn ’ t it nice of him to say he ’ d call ? You know , he never goes anywhere .

sp.speaker: WITHERS
sp.p: I can see Mrs. Jennings ’ face when she hears that the Count has been to see you , my dear .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Why do you say that ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: The Count lives next door to them in the country , and they ’ ve moved heaven and earth to know him , but he simply won ’ t look at them . Maria would give her eyes if he ’ d call on her .

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: How can you say such horrid things about her !

div.stage: During the last two or three speeches MR. and MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS come down the steps , followed by ETHEL , VINCENT and SERLO . SERLO goes over to talk to a flashily dressed girl at another table . PARKER-JENNINGS is a little stoutish man , very common and self-assertive . His wife is of a determined appearance , vulgar , and magnificently dressed . VINCENT is showy and aggressive . ETHEL is very charming and very pretty . SERLO is quite insignificant . MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS comes down the centre of the stage , with her party , elaborately ignoring LADY WANLEY ’ S table . ROSIE gets up and goes to her impulsively . MRS. WITHERS and her husband rise .

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: Mrs. Jennings , I am so glad to see you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Frigidly putting up her glasses .Mrs. Abbott .

sp.speaker: WITHERS
sp.p: Hullo , Bob , old man , how are the chicks ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: We ’ re all in the best of ’ ealth , thank you .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Shaking hands with MRS. WITHERS .I was hoping we should have a chance of speaking to you .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: What a picture you look , my dear ! What ’ s the matter with Vincent ? Why are you trying to look as if you ’ d never seen me before ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: You ’ ll never allow me to forget you , Mrs. Withers .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: No , I won ’ t . And many ’ s the time I ’ ve bathed you , my lad , in that little back room in St. John ’ s Road , Brixton , and don ’ t you forget that either .

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: Enthusiastically to MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS .Aren ’ t you surprised to see us here ? Mr. and Mrs. Withers are giving us such a treat .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I shouldn ’ t ’ ave thought this quite the place for a clergyman ’ s wife to come to . I confess I ’ m surprised you should find time to leave your work at Taverner in order to gad about in London .

div.stage: ROSIE is taken aback by the snub , and her face falls .

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: But we ’ re only here for a day or two . We shall be home on Thursday . I was wondering if I might come up to luncheon as Lewis has got to go out .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I ’ m expecting Lord Serlo ’ s mother and Lady Eleanor King to stay with me , so perhaps you ’ d better not come up to the ’ all for a few days . I ’ m sure you understand , don ’ t you . I don ’ t want to ’ urt your feelings , but I don ’ t think you ’ re quite the sort of person they ’ d like to meet .

div.stage: ROSIE gives a little gasp .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Indignantly .Mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I ’ ll let you know when it ’ s convenient for you to call . I ’ m afraid you ’ re a little inclined to be pushing , my dear . You don ’ t mind my telling you , do you ? It ’ s not quite the correct thing in a clergyman ’ s wife .

div.stage: She turns her back on ROSIE , who is left gasping . She tries to choke her sobs , but tears of mortification roll down her cheeks .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Oh , the cad , the cad .

div.stage: She makes ROSIE sit down and comforts her .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Mother , how could you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Hold your tongue , Ethel . I ’ ve been wanting to give those people a lesson for some time . Where ’ s our table , Robert ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: There are some people sitting there , my dear . We shall ’ ave to take this one .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Didn ’ t you tell the waiter to reserve it ? Waiter !

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Yes , madam .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: You must tell those people that that table ’ s taken .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I ’ m very sorry , madam . Will this one not do instead ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Yes , mother . Let ’ s sit here .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I ’ m not going to let people push me into any ’ ole and corner they like .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Cheek , I call it .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Come on , sit down , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Unwillingly taking her seat at a vacant table .How often ’ ave I told you not to call me mother ? My name ’ s Marion ; I ’ m sure you ought to know it by now .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Is it ? I always thought it was Maria .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: To JACK STRAW .What are you waiting there for ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I thought the gentleman wished to give an order , madam .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Why didn ’ t you keep that table , eh ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I ’ m very sorry , madam , I daresay I misunderstood you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Don ’ t you know English ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Perfectly , madam .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I don ’ t know what they want to engage these dirty foreigners for , they make me sick .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Mother , he can hear every word you say .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Two coffees , and bring all the liqueurs you ’ ve got .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Very well , sir , cigars or cigarettes ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Bring some cigars , and none of your twopenny stinkers . Bring the most expensive cigars you ’ ve got . I ’ ll soon show them who I am .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Very well , sir .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Mother , how could you be so brutal to poor Rosie . What has she done to you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I wish you wouldn ’ t call me mother , Ethel . It sounds so common . Why don ’ t you call me mamma ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Who ’ s ’ is lordship talking to ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Oh , that ’ s little Flossie Squaretoes . I ’ ll go and give her a look up in a minute .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I wish you were a little more like your brother , Ethel . He knows ’ ow to live up to ’ is position .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Aitches , mater , aitches .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , you always say I drop my aitches , Vincent . Well , if I do I can afford it .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: You ’ re wrong , mater , only the aristocracy can afford to drop their aitches .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , well , p ’ raps we shall be aristocracy one of these days , eh , Robert ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: You leave it to me , my dear . If money can do it .... I say , ’ is lordship lapped up that ’ ock of mine at luncheon , didn ’ t he ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I wish you could get out of that ’ abit of yours of always looking at what people eat and drink . And what if he did lap it up . You didn ’ t put it there for people to look at , did you ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: I say , Ethel , you needn ’ t have turned your back on him all the time .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I thought he drank too much .

lg.l: Your ideas are so beastly middle-class . You mustn ’ t expect a man like
Serlo to do things like — like the people we used to know at ....

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: That ’ ll do , Vincent . We all know quite well where we used to live before your father ’ s poor uncle was taken , and you needn ’ t refer to it .ETHEL shrugs her shoulders impatiently .It seems to me that Vincent and I are the only ones of the family who know ’ ow to live up to our position .JACK STRAW comes up with the coffee and liqueurs . Another waiter hands round the cigars . SERLO rejoins them .Very affably .Come and sit by me , Lord Serlo . Now what liqueurs will you ’ ave ? If there ’ s anything you fancy , you just ask for it .

div.stage: ROSIE gives a little sob .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Oh , my dear , don ’ t , don ’ t . You mustn ’ t mind .

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: I feel so frightfully humiliated . She asked me to go to the hall whenever I felt inclined , and I thought she really meant it . I never knew that I wasn ’ t wanted . It ’ s so awful to know that they only thought me horribly pushing .

sp.speaker: ABBOTT
sp.p: By Jove , I wish it had been one of the men . I should have liked to knock him down and stamp on him .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: My dear Lewis , how nice and unchristian of you ! I always said you were just the right sort of saint for me .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: Wouldn ’ t you like to come away now , my dear ?

sp.speaker: ROSIE
sp.p: Oh yes , I feel I want to hide myself .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Good-bye darling , don ’ t take it too much to heart .The WITHERS , ABBOTT , and ROSIE shake hands with HOLLAND and LADY WANLEY , and go out .Did you ever hear anything so fiendish ? Oh , if I could only make that woman suffer as she ’ s made poor little Rosie suffer .Suddenly LADY WANLEY gets an idea . She leans forward .Ambrose .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: What ’ s the matter ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I ’ ve got it .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: What d ’ you mean ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: One of these days Mrs. Jennings will give her eyes not to have insulted that poor child . I ’ m going to give her a lesson that she ’ ll never forget .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: She deserves pretty well anything that your feminine spite can suggest .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I can do nothing without you , Ambrose .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Don ’ t ask me to do anything very disreputable .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I ’ ve got her in the hollow of my hand , Ambrose .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Don ’ t you remember that story Adrian von Bremer told us about the attaché ? Let ’ s try it on Mrs. Jennings .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: But ....

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Oh , don ’ t make any objections . You must remember . He introduced his valet to a woman as a foreign nobleman of sorts .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I ’ m bound to say I thought it a very silly trick .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I have no patience with you . Think how exactly the punishment fits the crime . What a triumph it would be if we got Mrs. Parker-Jennings to take to her bosom ....

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Your friend the waiter . I ’ m sure he ’ ll do it if you ask him . He ’ ll look upon it as an adventure .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I don ’ t think he ’ d do it . He ’ s an odd fellow .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Oh , but ask him . There can be no harm in that .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: It ’ s all very well . But one has to consider the possible complications .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: There can ’ t be any complications . We only want to punish an insolent snob who ’ s wantonly insulted a woman who never hurt a fly in her life .

div.stage: JACK STRAW comes up to their table .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Have you done with the Benedictine , sir ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Mr . Straw , will you do something for me ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Anything in the world , madam .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Mr. Holland tells me you ’ re a man of spirit .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Pray tell Mr. Holland he ’ s a man of discernment .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Are you ready still for any adventure that comes your way ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: So long as I can do it with clean hands .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Dear me .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I daresay your ladyship thinks it odd that a waiter should have susceptibilities .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Let me tell you at once that I highly disapprove of Lady Wanley ’ s idea .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Then pray let me hear it . You always disapprove of everything that is not hopelessly commonplace .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: You told us just now that you were only temporarily engaged here .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Quite right , madam .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: You see those people over there — two women and three men ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: The elder lady was so amiable as to call me a dirty foreigner .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: They ’ re the worst sort of parvenus . I think they ’ re the greatest snobs in London . I have a little grudge against them .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Slightly embarrassed .I want to introduce you to them — as a foreign nobleman .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Giving her a searching look .Why ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Loudly .Waiter .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: It would amuse me to see them fawn upon you .

div.stage: A pause .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: No , I ’ m afraid I can ’ t do that .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Frigidly .Then we ’ ll say no more about it .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Loudly .Waiter .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Going to him .Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Why the devil don ’ t you hurry up . I ’ ve called three times .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Blandly .I ’ m very sorry , sir . I was engaged at another table .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: You seem to think you can keep me waiting all day . I suppose that ’ s why you ’ re called a waiter .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Robert , don ’ t make jokes with menials .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I ’ ve got a good mind to report you to the management .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Papa , he came as quickly as he could .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: This coffee ’ s disgusting . I don ’ t know what you make it out of . It tastes like ditchwater .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I ’ m very sorry , sir . Let me get you some more .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: And look sharp about it , or you ’ ll find yourself decorated with an order you don ’ t know in your country .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I beg your pardon , sir ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: The order of the boot .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: I can ’ t think why they don ’ t have English waiters in a smart hotel like this instead of these damned foreigners .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Now then , look slippy .

div.stage: JACK STRAW has fixed his eyes on ETHEL . She has been looking down . She gives him a glance . He takes the coffee things and gives them to another waiter .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Her voice trembling with indignation .How can you talk like that to a man who can ’ t defend himself ! It ’ s so cowardly to insult a servant who daren ’ t answer .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: I should think not indeed . I should like to see any servant answer me .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: You never ’ ave learnt ’ ow to treat servants , Ethel . You always talk to them as if they was one of ourselves . I wish you could take a leaf out of Vincent ’ s book . Treat ’ em like dirt , and they ’ ll respect you .

div.stage: JACK STRAW , having given instructions to the waiter , goes to HOLLAND and LADY WANLEY .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I ’ m willing to do what you asked me to .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Why have you changed your mind ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: To tell you the truth I ’ m perfectly indifferent to the rudeness and the vulgarity of your friends , but I think I should like to know that young lady .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Would you , by Jove !

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: When her father insulted me , the most ravishing colour came into her pale cheeks , and she looked at me with the most beautiful eyes in the world . And they were veiled with tears .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: And is that enough to make you change your mind ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Fortunately Mr . Straw is not in the habit of falling in love , or I should refuse to hear anything more of this cracked-brained scheme .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: When will you be ready ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I ’ m ready now . It ’ s three o ’ clock , and Pierre is waiting in the basement to put on this uniform .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: We couldn ’ t find a better place than this to effect an introduction .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Give me two minutes to change my clothes , and I am at your service .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: You have indeed an adventurous spirit .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: But I must make one condition — two , in fact .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: What are they ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Well , although you have glided over the point with singular discretion , it is plain that you do not want me to assume a certain character merely in order to enjoy a private snigger at the expense of these amiable people .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I don ’ t think I know what you mean ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Madam , it is always dangerous to count too much on the stupidity of one ’ s fellows . We shall arrange this matter much better if you realise that I ’ m a person of some shrewdness .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Go on .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It is evident that you wish these good folk to take me to their bosom in order that you may have the opportunity of telling them one day that I ’ m merely an impostor .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I really hadn ’ t thought about that .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I venture to suspect that you rate your intelligence too low .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Well , what is your condition ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: The position will be very humiliating to me . For all I know it may bring me into uncomfortable relations with the police .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I think the whole plan had better be dropped . It will lead to endless bother .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I have no wish to drop it . You want to revenge yourself on some people who have insulted you . I , for reasons of my own , am willing to help . But I make the condition that you do not disclose the truth till I give you leave . I promise not to withhold it unreasonably .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I accept that . And the second condition ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Is very easy . I insist that you should behave towards me , whether we ’ re alone or in public , as you naturally would if I were really the individual I propose to personate .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: That ’ s only fair . Now who can we suggest that you should be ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: You ’ d better try and invent some character who you ’ re quite sure doesn ’ t exist .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: We want something very extravagant and high-sounding .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Pray do not put yourselves to the trouble of thinking . You will introduce me to your friends as the Archduke Sebastian of Pomerania .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: But that ’ s a real person !

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: To invent an imaginary one would be ridiculous . Your friends would only need to look in the Almanack de Gotha to discover the fraud .

lg.l: But Count von Bremer was talking to us about him just now . The Archduke
Sebastian is the man who mysteriously disappeared .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It ’ s because his whereabouts are unknown that he ’ s the safest person to choose .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: You would never be able to pass yourself off for an Archduke .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Strange as it may seem to you , a royal prince eats , drinks , breathes , and behaves generally very much like men of baser clay .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: You ’ d be found out in a week .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: But how do you know I ’ m not the Archduke Sebastian ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: With a scornful laugh .You look it .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: But you ’ d want a suite and all sorts of things .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: The man is notoriously eccentric . I think it very likely that the company of a stuffy old Colonel of Dragoons would bore him to death .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: It ’ s preposterous .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You may either take it or leave it . I will be the Archduke Sebastian or nobody .

lg.l: After all , Mrs. Jennings will probably never have heard of this trumpery
Archduke .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: And if she has , what more probable than that , having had enough of retirement , he should enter once more upon the position which is his by rights ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Looking at HOLLAND .It makes the joke infinitely better .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You must make up your minds at once .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Ambrose , let ’ s toss . Heads it is , and tails it isn ’ t .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: All right .He tosses a coin .Tails .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I said , tails it is , didn ’ t I ?... I ’ m willing to risk it .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Give me two minutes .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Heaven only knows what will be the end of it .

div.stage: LORD SERLO comes up to them .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Hello , Ambrose . How ’ s life ? How d ’ ye do ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: What have you been doing ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: I ’ ve been lettin ’ Jennings ’ Patent Hardware stand me a lunch . My word , that old woman ’ s so vulgar she just about takes the roof of your head off .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Why do you lunch with people you thoroughly despise ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Despise ’ em ! I don ’ t despise people who ’ ve got eighty thousand a year . They ’ re trying to hook me for their girl .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: And are you proposing to — throw yourself away ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: She ’ s a very neat-steppin ’ little filly — swallowed a poker in her childhood — regrettable accident in the nursery , don ’ t you know , but sound in wind and limb and all that sort of thing .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I admire your romantic air .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Whoever talked of romance ? There ’ s half a million down on one side and an old-established marquisate on the other .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: When is the happy event to take place ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Well , as soon as we can get over a triflin ’ impediment .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: What ’ s that ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Well , the filly ’ s kicking . Have to put a red ribbon on her tail , don ’ t you know .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: She ’ s refusing the coronet you lay at her feet ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Won ’ t touch it with the fag end of a barge pole . I was sittin ’ next to her at lunch , and she simply turned her back on me — no mistakin ’ it , don ’ t you know . Wouldn ’ t let me get a word in edgeways . Mother ’ s all over me , father ’ s all over me , son ’ s all over me . What ’ s the good of that ? Can ’ t marry them . Rotten , I call it . Came over here to have a bit of a rest .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Laughing .And how d ’ you like Vincent ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Rotten bounder . Can ’ t stick him at any price , knows too many lords for me . When he ’ s my brother-in-law — hoof him out , don ’ t you know — double quick march . Pretty Polly ’ s all very well but I ’ m not takin ’ her family . Can ’ t do it for half a million , don ’ t you know . Must be practical .

div.stage: VINCENT comes up to them .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: How d ’ you do , Lady Wanley ? I saw you driving with Lady Mary Ware yesterday . Such a nice girl , isn ’ t she ? I suppose you know her brother Tregury , don ’ t you ? Great pal of mine at Oxford .

lg.l: He ’ s my second cousin , Mr. Jennings , and he pronounces his name
Tregary .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Oh yes , of course . I always used to call him Tregury for fun .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Did you ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: You have a very keen sense of humour .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: I was just having an argument with the mater as to what relation he was to the Duke of Sherwin .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I ’ m afraid I haven ’ t your intimate knowledge of the peerage , but I should think the only relation they ’ ve had in common for the last two centuries is that lamented monarch , Charles II .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: To SERLO .Nice chap , Sherwin .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Dunno him .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Don ’ t you ? Not know Sherwin ? I must introduce you to him . I ’ m sure he ’ d like to know you . Thorough sportsman .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Is he ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Yes , rather . I saw him looking on at a cricket match the other day . Great pal of my governor ’ s , you know . Thorough English gentleman .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: They ’ d get on well together .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: To HOLLAND .Here is our friend . JACK STRAW comes in , hat and cane in hand . He wears a very smart suit , tail coat , grey trousers , & c .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I ’ m so sorry I couldn ’ t come to lunch with you .

div.stage: He shakes LADY WANLEY ’ S hand , she slightly curtsies to him . MRS. JENNINGS nudges her husband , and they both stare with all their eyes .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: It ’ s very good of you to have come now , sir .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Ah , my dear Holland , you are looking the picture of health .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: It ’ s very kind of you , sir .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: May I introduce Lord Serlo to you ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Shaking hands with him .How d ’ you do . I think your father was ambassador in Pomerania for some time .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Yes , he was .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Surprised .How did you know that — sir ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I remember him quite well . He used to play with me when I was a little boy . I was so sorry to hear of his death .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: He wasn ’ t a bad old buffer . Kept me dooced short of money , though .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Gaily .But unless you introduce me to Lord Serlo he won ’ t know who on earth I am .

lg.l: I thought every one knew , at least by sight , the — Archduke Sebastian of
Pomerania .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You talk of me as if I were a notorious character .Meanwhile VINCENT has been making frantic signs to be introduced , coughing and shuffling on his feet . JACK STRAW looks at him through his eyeglass .Won ’ t you introduce your friend to me ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Mr. Vincent Parker-Jennings .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: I ’ m very proud and honoured to make your Royal Highness ’ s acquaintance .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It ’ s very polite of you to say so .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: I ’ ve always had a great sympathy for Pomerania . Most wonderful country in Europe , that ’ s what I always say .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I will tell my grandfather you think so . He will be pleased and flattered .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: I haven ’ t ever been there , you know , sir . But I know all about it through Adrian von Bremer .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Hastily .Your ambassador lives quite near Mr. Jennings .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Oh yes .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: His place marches with ours , don ’ t you know . He ’ s a great pal of my people ’ s . Jolly old thing , isn ’ t he , sir ? Thorough sportsman . That ’ s what I call a gentleman .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I seem to know your name so well .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Mr. Parker-Jennings is the great philanthropist . He ’ s provided books to put in all Mr. Carnegie ’ s free libraries .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: What a noble act . I should very much like to make his acquaintance .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: He ’ s sitting over there with my mother and sister . Shall I go and fetch him , sir ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It ’ s very kind of you to take so much trouble .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: To JACK STRAW in an undertone .For goodness sake be careful .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Putting up his eyeglass .I beg your pardon , I did not catch what you said .... Pray repeat it .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Embarrassed .It was of no consequence , sir .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: To VINCENT .Who is he , Vincent ? I saw ’ er curtsey to him .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Come along , pater . He wants to be introduced to you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I ’ m coming too , Vincent .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Awfully jolly chap . Archduke Sebastian . What ho !

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: But look here , Vincent , I don ’ t know how to talk to Royalty . How shall I address him ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Oh , that ’ s all right . Say Sir wherever you can slip it in and when you can ’ t say Royal Highness .

div.stage: JACK STRAW comes forward a little with LADY WANLEY .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: This is Mrs. Parker-Jennings .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Shaking hands with her .I ’ m delighted to make your acquaintance .Turning to PARKER-JENNINGS .I have often heard of you , Mr .... Mr ....

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Prompting .Parker-Jennings .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: With a relieved smile .Mr. Parker-Jennings . I ’ m sure I wish we had in my country more men of your public spirit and disinterestedness .

lg.l: I try to do my little best , you know , sir , your
Royal Highness .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Won ’ t you introduce me to your daughter ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I ’ m sure , sir , your Royal Highness is very affable . Ethel !

div.stage: ETHEL slowly comes forward , and curtsies . He looks at her steadily , takes her hand and kisses it .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: In an undertone .What ho !

div.stage: END OF THE FIRST ACT .

div.head: THE SECOND ACT

stage.stage: The drawing-room at Taverner , the PARKER-JENNINGS ’ place in Cheshire . Large French windows lead out on to the garden . MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS , magnificently dressed , is standing in the middle of the room . PARKER-JENNINGS comes in , rubbing his hands .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: The band has come , my dear , and they ’ re ready to start playing the moment any one turns up .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: ’ Ave you told ’ em about the Pomeranian anthem ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: What do you think , my dear ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I wish you wouldn ’ t answer me like that . Why don ’ t you say yes or no ? I can ’ t abide these city ways of yours .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I was only being facetious , my dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I should ’ ave thought you ’ d learned by now that it ’ s vulgar to be funny . You ’ ve never ’ eard a duchess make a joke , ’ ave you ? VINCENT comes in .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: I ’ ve just been round the refreshment tents . There ’ s one thing , people can ’ t say we haven ’ t spread ourselves out .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Rubbing his hands .I ’ aven ’ t spared a single expense . The band ’ s down from London , and the refreshments are from Gunter ’ s . There ’ s not a cigar on the place that cost less than one and six — and that ’ s the wholesale price .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , we ’ ve done it well , there ’ s no denying that . I ’ ve asked the Withers , Robert . Florrie Withers will be mad with jealousy . I shouldn ’ t wonder if she didn ’ t choke with envy when she swallowed a caviar sandwich .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: It was a rare stroke of business when we got the Archduke to come and stay .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: That ’ s through me , pater . You ’ d never have known him if I hadn ’ t been on the spot .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: And I ’ ve asked Lady Wanley . I just want her to see that I can get on without her . All the county ’ s coming . I sent ’ em all cards , whether I knew ’ em or not , and they ’ ve all accepted .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Don ’ t you remember , Marion , how bucked we were in the old days when Mrs. Bromsgrove came to dine with us , because her husband was on the L. C. C . ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I wish she could see me now . D ’ you remember ’ ow she used to patronise me ? I wish all that stuck-up lot on Brixton ’ ill was here to see us ’ ob-nob with the aristocracy .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: It ’ s the Archduke that done it , my dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: What ’ s Serlo now ? Marquis of Serlo — pooh . He isn ’ t going to get any more opportunities from me — and if he says anything I ’ ll just send him off with a flea in his ear .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Draw it mild , mater .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Your mother ’ s a great woman , Vincent . This is the day of her life .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I wish I ’ adn ’ t been such a fool as to ask Serlo to stay here . And it ’ s just like that aggravating girl . When I wanted Ethel to marry him , she wouldn ’ t so much as look at him , and now that she can have some one else for the asking , she ’ s with ’ im all day .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Well , I ’ m for the bird in the hand , mater . The Archduke don ’ t look much like a marrying man to me .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Don ’ t you worry about that , my dear . Every man ’ s a marrying man when he ’ s got a chance of a pretty girl with ’ alf a million of money .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Here she is . ETHEL comes in with LORD SERLO .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: The Withers have just motored over , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: They would be first , wouldn ’ t they ? I expect Florrie Withers was waiting on the doorstep till the clock struck four . Where ’ s his Royal Highness ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I don ’ t know at all .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: He ’ s asleep in the garden ; he ’ s sittin ’ in the most comfortable arm-chair in the place , with another for each of his legs , and he ’ s clasping in his hands what looks suspiciously like a very long gin and soda to me .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well , somebody must go and wake him up . I ’ ve asked ’ alf the county to meet him , and he can ’ t go on sleeping . JACK STRAW comes in .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I say , what have you got a beastly band playing the Pomeranian anthem for ? Woke me up . I was having such a jolly sleep too .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Very affably .The people are just coming , sir .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: What people ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: All the very best people in Cheshire , sir — no outsiders to-day . What ho !

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Good lord , are you giving a party ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Don ’ t you remember , sir ? I asked if I might invite a few friends to meet you .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Oh , yes — Lady Wanley and Holland . I thought we might have a jolly little game of bridge in the garden . What have you got the village band in for ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: That ’ s not the village band , sir . That ’ s the Royal Blue Orchestra .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Cost me £ 150 to have them down . Special train from London , and I don ’ t know what all .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Shut up , pater . You needn ’ t tell every one how much you paid for things .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: How many do you expect ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh — only my most intimate friends — about ....

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well , about three hundred and fifty .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: By George , that ’ s cheerful . D ’ you want me to shake hands with them all ?

lg.l: They ’ re the very best people in the county , sir . Crème de la crème .
A servant enters to announce MR. and MRS. WITHERS .
They come in .

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Mr. and Mrs. Withers .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: How d ’ you do ? It ’ s so nice of you to come before any one else .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: We know you ’ re not used to these grand affairs , Maria , and we thought you might want a couple of old friends to do something for you .

lg.l: Oh , thank you . But there are plenty of servants . May I introduce Mr. and
Mrs. Withers to your Royal ’ Ighness .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: How d ’ you do .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: We were just going into the garden . I daresay people will begin to come presently .

div.stage: They all go out except ETHEL and LORD SERLO .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: I say , I ’ m going to hook it to-morrow .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Are you ? I ’ m very sorry .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: I wish I thought that .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Why are you going so soon ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Your respected mother has given your humble notice to quit .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Look here , let ’ s be frank with one another , shall we ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Aren ’ t we always ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Well , if you ask me point blank , anythin ’ but .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Then let us be frank at once .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Well , ten days ago your people were all over me . I suppose you know why as well as I do .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: D ’ you think we need talk of that ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Frankness is rather tryin ’, ain ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: No . Please go on .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: It was dear Lord Serlo all day long ; they couldn ’ t have enough of me . Rippin ’ good chap , Serlo . Just the sort of cove one would like to have for a son-in-law .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Lord Serlo !

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Half a mo . I ain ’ t done yet . Eminently suitable match , and all that sort of thing , only the young lady couldn ’ t stick me at any price .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I don ’ t know why you should say this .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Better have it out , you know ; rotten , keepin ’ things on your chest . Don ’ t blame the young lady . Don ’ t know that I should much fancy myself if I was a blushing damsel . Not everybody ’ s money . Got a bit damaged in transit , eh , what ? Been mixed up in one or two scandals . Not the right thing for an old-established marquess . Bit inclined to drink . No harm in him , you know , but not the sort of man you ’ d like to spend the rest of your life with . Young woman got a mind of her own . Lets the noble lord see she wouldn ’ t take him if he was given away with a pound of tea . All right , says noble lord , bet ’ s off . Not much , says mother of young woman . Half a million goin ’ beggin ’. Give her time to get used to you . Fascinating cove really . More she knows you more she ’ ll like you . Come down and stay in the country .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: With a laugh .How can you talk such nonsense !

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: All right , says noble lord , I ’ m on . Jolly nice girl , and all that sort of thing . Noble lord rather smit . Thinks if she ’ ll have him he ’ ll turn over a new leaf — give up everythin ’ rotten and try and make her a good husband . Rather taken with the idea of double harness . He may look a fool , but noble lord knows a good thing when he sees it , and the young lady ’ s about the best thing he ’ s ever set eyes on .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Are you talking seriously by any chance ?

lg.l: Now don ’ t interrupt me . I ’ ve just got into a good steady canter , and
I ’ ll get it all off my chest at once .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I ’ m so sorry .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Well , when eligible marquess gets down in the country , what d ’ you think he finds ? Blessed if there ain ’ t a foreign prince on the scene . My word , that ’ s enough to put the noble lord ’ s aristocratic nose right out of joint , ain ’ t it ? Look here , old boy , you keep your weather eye open , and all that sort of thing , says the noble lord to himself . May be an ass , don ’ t you know , but when there ’ s a bloomin ’ hurricane comin ’ along he can see which way the wind is blowin ’. Brother rather chilly , father rather chilly , mother regular iceberg . All right , says noble lord to himself , but what about Pretty Polly ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Is that me by any chance ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: For the last month Pretty Polly had been simply turnin ’ her back on noble lord , snubbin ’ him right and left , and all of a sudden she becomes extraordinary affable . Hulloa , what ’ s this , says noble lord , and his little heart goes pit-a-pat . He may be a fool , but he ain ’ t a damned fool , and in a day or two he tumbles to it . So , like a wise man , he packs his bag and hooks it .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I don ’ t know what on earth you mean ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Don ’ t you ? Well , will you have it straight from the shoulder ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: We agreed to be quite frank .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: All right . No spoof . My dear , I just saw that you were fairly knocked silly by the Archduke , and there wasn ’ t a ghost of a chance for little Ned Serlo .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: It ’ s not true .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Oh , yes , it is . You see , I ’ m a bit knocked silly myself , and that makes you precious far-sighted .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You !

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: All right , you needn ’ t get up on your hind legs . I ’ m not goin ’ to propose to you now . I know it would be no precious good . At first I didn ’ t care twopence ; it was just a business arrangement — half a million down on one side and an old-established marquisate on the other . But now .... Well , you know I ’ m rather an ass at saying what I mean — when I really mean it .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I ’ m very sorry . I ’ m afraid I ’ ve been unkind to you .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Oh , no , you haven ’ t . I do seem a rotten little bounder , don ’ t I ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: No , I think you might be an awfully good friend .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: It ’ s jolly of you to say so . You know , I can ’ t stick your family . Can you ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Smiling .You see , I knew them before they were rich . When you ’ ve lived all your life in a sordid narrow way , it ’ s very hard to have such enormous wealth as ours .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: You make allowances for them , but you never did for me .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: It would have been very impertinent of me .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: It never struck you that it ’ s devilish hard to be a marquess with no means of livelihood but your title . And the worst of a title is that it ’ ll get you plenty of credit , but dooced little hard cash .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I never thought of that .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Well , look here , what I wanted to say is this : it ’ s no business of mine about the Archduke . You know , I don ’ t know much about royalty , but I don ’ t think a foreign prince is likely to marry the daughter of nobody in particular just because she ’ s got nice eyes and a pot of money .ETHEL is about to speak .No , let me go on . You may be going to have a rotten time , and I just want you to know that if at any time you want me — well , you know what I mean , don ’ t you . Let ’ s forget that you ’ re an heiress , and I ’ m an old-established marquess . You ’ re an awfully ripping sort , and I ’ m just Ned Serlo . I ’ m not a bad sort either , and perhaps we might be happy together .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Touched .It ’ s very charming of you . I ’ m so glad that I know you better now . Whatever happens I know I can count on you .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: That ’ s all right then . Meanwhile noble lord ’ s goin ’ to hook it — leave the coast clear , and bear it like a man , don ’ t you know .

div.stage: Enter JACK STRAW .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Well , how are the weather and the crops ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Rather surprised .Blessed if I know , sir .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I merely asked because you looked as if you ’ d been discussing them .

div.stage: He gives SERLO a glance . SERLO shows no sign of moving .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I ’ m not driving you away , am I ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Getting up .Not at all , sir . I thought I ’ d go and have a look at the party .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Do go and pretend you ’ re me , there ’ s a good fellow , and shake hands with some of those confounded people . You ’ ll see where I ought to stand , because there ’ s a little piece of red carpet on the lawn .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: I ’ m afraid they ’ re not takin ’ any of me , sir .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: The only advantage I ’ ve ever been able to find in being a royal personage is that when anybody ’ s in your way you just tell him to go , and he goes .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Why did you want Lord Serlo to go , sir ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Because I wanted to be alone with you . Ask me another , quickly .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Oughtn ’ t I to help mother to receive people ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I ’ m sure you ought . But , you see , that ’ s another advantage of being a royal personage , that you can ’ t go till I give you your dismissal . I say , don ’ t you hate parties ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Dreadfully .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: So do I. Let ’ s pretend there isn ’ t one , shall we ? I say , why don ’ t you sit down and make yourself comfy ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I should like to have a little talk with you , sir .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: That ’ s jolly . I wish we had a regiment of soldiers there to turn all those people out .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: May I say anything I like to you , sir ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Good heavens , why not ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Until I was sixteen the most exalted person I ’ d ever met in my life was a London County Councillor . I ’ m not quite sure if I know how to behave with royal personages .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Why on earth don ’ t you buy a book on etiquette ? I always carry one about with me .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Mother bought several when you said you ’ d come down .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I wonder if she ’ s got the same as mine . You know I never can remember to call a serviette a napkin .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Mamma ’ s very particular about that .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: And look here , d ’ you know that you ought never to call a chicken a fowl ? It ’ s awfully bad form . I wonder if that ’ s in your mother ’ s books . I say , what charming eyes you have .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: That ’ s another of the advantages of being a royal personage , that you can make pretty speeches , and no one takes them seriously .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: But you know , I ’ m a very insignificant royal personage . You mustn ’ t think I ’ m anything very grand really .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: It ’ s very nice of you to say so .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You see , there are seventy-nine archdukes and duchesses in Pomerania . My grandfather had seventeen children , and they all married . How many children would each have had to make seventy-nine of us ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: It sounds very difficult .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: But you see I can ’ t be very important , can I ? And of course I ’ ve got practically no money to speak of .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: It ’ s very good of you to put me at my ease . Then you wont mind if I say exactly what I want to ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You won ’ t give me good advice , will you ? I ’ ve got seventy-nine relations , and they all do that .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I wouldn ’ t venture .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I ’ ll bear whatever else you say with fortitude . We ’ ll pretend that you ’ re just Miss So-and-So .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: As in point of fact , I am .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: And that I ’ m — Jack Straw .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Surprised .Why on earth Jack Straw ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Indifferently .It ’ s the name of a public-house in Hampstead . Pray go on .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I wondered if you ’ d do me a great favour .

lg.l: Ask me for the moon , and it shall be left at your front door by Carter
Paterson to-morrow morning .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: It ’ s something much simpler than that .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Put me out of suspense quickly .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I should be very much obliged if — if you ’ d go away .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Much surprised .I ? Now ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I didn ’ t mean actually this minute . But if it suited your arrangements to go to-morrow ....

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You don ’ t mean to say you want me to go away altogether ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: That is precisely what I did mean .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Couldn ’ t you ask me something easier than that ? Ask me for a lawyer who never told a lie , and I ’ ll deliver him to you , bound hand and foot .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I don ’ t happen to want one just at this moment , thank you .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: But I ’ m having a very jolly time down here .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: With a change of tone .Don ’ t you see that you ’ re exposing me every day to the most cruel humiliation ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I thought I was making myself so pleasant .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Oh , don ’ t pretend you don ’ t understand . I ’ ve seen the twinkle in your eyes when my mother set a little trap for you to fall in .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I always fall in very neatly .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: But what do you think I felt when I knew how clearly you saw that she was throwing me at your head ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It ’ s a distinctly pleasing sensation to have a pretty girl thrown at your head .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: It was only a joke to you ; you don ’ t know how ashamed I was .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: But why do you suppose I came down to Taverner — to see your father and mother ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I don ’ t know why you came — unless it was to make me desperately wretched .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: What would you say if I told you that I came because I loved you at first sight ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I should say that your Royal Highness was very polite .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Now , look here , don ’ t you think I ’ m rather nice , really ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: It would surely be very impertinent of me to have any opinion on the subject .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Our friend Serlo would describe that as one in the eye .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Would you allow me to go back to my mother ’ s guests , sir ?

lg.l: Do you think you ’ d like me any better if I weren ’ t an
Archduke ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I haven ’ t thought about it .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Then please give the matter your immediate attention .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I should certainly like you no less .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I have no doubt that if I were just a penniless adventurer you ’ d simply dote upon me .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I don ’ t know if I ’ d put it quite so strongly as that .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You know , I ’ m afraid you ’ re hopelessly romantic . You ’ ve confessed your attachment to me , and just because I happen incautiously to have chosen an Emperor for my grandfather , you want me to go away . It ’ s so unreasonable .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: But I haven ’ t confessed anything of the sort .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I look upon your request that I should go away as equivalent to an avowal of undying passion .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Shall I tell you what I would say to you if you weren ’ t an Archduke ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I ’ d say you were the most audacious , impudent , and impertinent man I ’ d ever seen in my life .

div.stage: She gives a rapid , ironical curtsey , and goes out . He is about to follow her when LADY WANLEY and HOLLAND come in . JACK STRAW stops and shakes hands with them .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Ah , I was hoping to have the pleasure of seeing you . You wrote me a little note , Mr. Holland .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Ironically .I ventured to ask if I might have a few minutes ’ private conversation with you .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Perhaps you wouldn ’ t mind waiting here . I will rejoin you immediately .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: You know , he positively freezes me .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I think it ’ s wonderful . One couldn ’ t suspect for a moment that he ’ s only ....

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Take care .

div.stage: He looks round .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: No one will come here . We can talk quite safely .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I wish to goodness we hadn ’ t ever thought of this fool trick . I knew it would lead to all sorts of bother .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: It ’ s no good saying that now . We must keep our heads and get out of it as best we can .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Oh , that ’ s just like a man . You ’ re trying to put the whole blame on me . What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Well , we must finish with it as quickly as we can .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Whatever happens , there must be no scene . I couldn ’ t bear to see him publicly humiliated .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Why on earth should you think of him ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Oh , I ’ m such a fool , Ambrose .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: My dear , what do you mean ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: After all , I ’ m not a girl — I ’ m the mother of two healthy boys with enormous appetites . I think the man has bewitched me .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Good Lord !

lg.l: It ’ s no good saying that . Of course he ’ s the most fascinating creature
I ’ ve ever seen in my life .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: You don ’ t mean to say you ’ re seriously in love with him ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: A widow with a sense of humour is never seriously in love with anybody .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: But I think it ’ s much better the young man should disappear as mysteriously as he came .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: There we ’ re quite agreed . And we ’ ll tell him so with considerable frankness .

div.stage: Enter JACK STRAW .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Now , my dear people , I am at your service .

div.stage: HOLLAND and LADY WANLEY are sitting down . JACK STRAW looks at HOLLAND , who rises uneasily .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Oh , don ’ t be such an ass , Jack .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Frigidly .I beg your pardon .Pause .Perhaps you ’ d be good enough to put down my hat .

div.stage: HOLLAND takes it and flings it crossly on a chair .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I don ’ t think you ’ re in a very good humour this afternoon , Mr. Holland . I venture to think your manners leave something to be desired .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Look here , we ’ ve had enough of this tomfoolery .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Pray sit down . It distresses me to see you standing .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I believe the man ’ s out of his senses .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Very amiably .Have you forgotten the waiter ’ s uniform which fitted you so wonderfully , Mr . Straw ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Calmly .Quite . I only remember the condition your ladyship was good enough to agree to , when I accepted your humorous suggestion .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: But , look here , we must talk the matter out .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I am quite willing to listen to you , my dear Holland . Your conversation is often interesting and sometimes epigrammatic . I stipulate only that you should use those forms of politeness which are usual between a person of your position and a person of mine .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I should never have consented to this folly if I ’ d known to what it was going to lead . In a moment of uncontrollable irritation , because Mrs. Jennings had behaved with the greatest insolence to a defenceless girl , we made up our minds to punish her . There was no great harm in it . We thought perhaps she ’ d ask you to dinner , and there would be an end of it . It never dawned on us that you ’ d come and stay here indefinitely .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: My dear fellow , why should you blame me for your own lack of intelligence ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Impatiently .Ugh !
