div.stage: JACK STRAW goes over and sits beside LADY WANLEY .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Our friend is quite incoherent , isn ’ t he ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: We want you to go away , sir .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Do you ? I say , what a jolly frock . Where did you get it ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: With a little laugh , disarmed by his impudence .You ’ re perfectly irresistible .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You ’ ve taken the words out of my mouth , that ’ s just what I was going to say to you .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Are you ever serious ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Always when I ’ m talking to a pretty woman .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I wish I could understand you .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: My dear lady , I ’ ve been trying to understand myself for the last thirty odd years . By the way , how old am I , Holland ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: How the deuce should I know ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Well , my dear fellow , I think it ’ s very careless of you . You might have looked it out . Supposing some one had asked me my age ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I wish you really were a royal personage .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It does seem hard that a waiter should have such a way with him , doesn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Confidentially .Who are you really ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Your devoted servant , madam . Who could be anything else after knowing you for ten minutes ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: It ’ s charming of you to say so .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I am very nice , aren ’ t I ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Much too nice . That is why I beseech your Royal Highness graciously to take his departure .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You know , you haven ’ t yet told me where you got that frock .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Oh , I bought it in Paris . Do you like it ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It ’ s ripping . And it suits you admirably .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Isabel , Isabel , we came here to be sensible .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: My dear Ambrose , let me be sensible in my own way .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Oh , my dear Holland , I wonder if you ’ d very much mind going to see if my red carpet is still in its place .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I ’ m not going to be made a fool of by you , my friend .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Why not ? You ’ re doing it very well .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Don ’ t be piggy , Ambrose .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: What on earth do you want me to do ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: I ’ m simply dying of thirst . I wish you ’ d get me a glass of lemonade .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I have no intention whatever of stirring from this spot .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I ’ ve been wondering for the last week what I should do if I signified his dismissal to any one , and he flatly refused to go . Very awkward , isn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Mahomet and the mountain isn ’ t in it .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Of course a hundred years ago I ’ d have cast him into a dungeon . But , between ourselves , I don ’ t happen to have a dungeon handy .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Now look here , we ’ ve had enough of this nonsense . The joke has gone far enough . Are you going or not ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Well , if you ask me point blank , I ’ m not .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: But don ’ t you know that I have only to say two words for you to be kicked out of the house by the servants ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You forget that you ’ d be undoubtedly kicked out with me .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Now look here , Jack , we ’ ve been old pals , and we ’ ve gone through a deuce of a lot together . I don ’ t want to say beastly things to you . I know I ’ ve made a fool of myself , but you ’ re a decent chap . You must see that it ’ s necessary for you to go at once .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I cannot for the life of me see anything of the sort . I have no other engagements , and the country is charming at this time of year .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: You ’ re behaving like a common impostor .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: What language to use to a royal personage ! I assure you we ’ re not used to such frankness .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Do you deliberately refuse to go ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Deliberately .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: And shall I tell you why ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I happen to know , thank you .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: You ’ re going to commit the most disgraceful action of your life . Do you think any one can ’ t see that you ’ re madly in love with Ethel Jennings ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Springing to her feet .Is that true ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Quite .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Then why have you been flirting with me so disgracefully ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I assure you I had no intention of doing so . It must be my unfortunate manner .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: It ’ s an unfortunate manner that ’ s quite likely to get you into trouble with widow ladies .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: In that case you can only applaud my determination to marry as quickly as possible .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Not Ethel Jennings ?

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: You must be joking ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: My dear madam , when I make a joke I always laugh quickly , so that there should be no doubt about it .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: It ’ s preposterous . I shall allow you to do nothing of the sort .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: My dear fellow , what is the use of getting violently excited about it ? More especially as I haven ’ t yet proposed to the young lady .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I think you must be stark staring mad . You don ’ t suppose for a moment that we shall allow you to carry out such an odious deception . I can ’ t imagine how you can even think of anything so heartless and cruel .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: It ’ s going too far . You must understand that it ’ s impossible . I beseech you to leave Taverner immediately .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It drives me to distraction that I should have to refuse your smallest whim , but in this matterwith a dramatic flourishI am adamant .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Now , look here , we ’ ve talked about it enough . Either you leave this place immediately or I shall tell Mrs. Jennings the whole story .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It is only fair to give you that satisfaction . That was part of our arrangement .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: You realise the consequences ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Very amiably .I did that before I entered into your scheme .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: You leave me no alternative .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: My dear Holland , I really believe you ’ re rather nervous about the disclosure which it is evidently your duty to make .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: For your own sake I ask you once more : will you give me your word of honour to leave the house and under no circumstances communicate with any member of the family ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It ’ s charming of you to give me one more chance . I can only repeat that I am deeply in love with Ethel , and I have every intention of marrying her .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Your blood be upon your own head .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: If I perish , I perish .

div.stage: HOLLAND goes to the door .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: No , Ambrose , I beseech you not to .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Good heavens , the whole thing was done so that you might have an opportunity to crow over Mrs. Jennings . Now you ’ re going to have it .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: But I don ’ t want it any more . It was a foolish thing . Let him go quietly .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: But , you see , he won ’ t go .

div.stage: Enter MR. and MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , your Royal ’ Ighness , we ’ ve been looking for you everywhere . We couldn ’ t make out what ’ ad become of you .

lg.l: All the county is there . Crème de la crème .
VINCENT comes in hurriedly .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: I say , mater , what on earth are you doing ? Hurry up , the duchess has just driven up .... Oh , I beg your pardon , sir . I didn ’ t know you were there .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Vincent , go and fetch your sister . I have something important to say that it is necessary for her to hear .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: But look here , the duchess has just ....

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Oh , hang the duchess . Where ’ s Ethel ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: She ’ s sitting just outside , talking to Serlo .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Then call her .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Looking round with astonishment .’ As anythin ’ appened ?

div.stage: VINCENT goes out and in a moment returns with ETHEL and SERLO .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: To HOLLAND .Ambrose , be gentle .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Your Royal Highness isn ’ t put out about anything ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Quickly .Oh , I ’ ope we ’ aven ’ t made any faux pas .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Nothing has happened to displease me . I ’ m in the best possible humour , thank you .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Seeing ETHEL .Oh , there you are .Addressing himself to the company in general .I have something very painful to say , and I don ’ t know how I ’ m going to make it clear to you .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: I say , is this any business of mine ? Shall I hook it ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Oh no , pray stay by all means .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: To JACK STRAW .Haven ’ t you changed your mind , sir ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I ’ m like a historical character whose name I can ’ t remember at the moment : I never change my mind .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Mrs. Jennings , I ’ m afraid there ’ s no use in my trying to excuse myself . I had better just tell you everything as shortly as I can .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Mr. Holland , don ’ t you think it can wait till later ? The duchess ’ as just come , and it ’ ll look so funny if I ’ m not there to receive her .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Mr. Holland has a communication to make which cannot fail to interest you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , of course , if it ’ s your Royal ’ Ighness ’ s wish .

lg.l: I daresay you remember that a fortnight ago we all met at the Grand
Babylon Hotel .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: How could I forget , when that was the auspicious occasion of my introduction to his Royal ’ Ighness .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Ambrose .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: You may remember , also , that Mr. and Mrs. Abbott were sitting with us in the lounge .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I ’ ave other things to do than to remember where Mr. and Mrs. Abbott were sitting .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I daresay you ’ ve forgotten that you behaved very cruelly to her . We were all very indignant . We thought it necessary to punish you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Really , Mr. Holland , I don ’ t know who you think you ’ re talking to .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I find it very difficult to say what I have to — I realise now that the whole business has been preposterously silly — I can manage far better if you don ’ t interrupt .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Please let him go on , Mrs. Jennings .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Of , of course , if your Royal ’ Ighness wishes it I ’ ave no more to say .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: It struck me that it would be amusing to pass off a nobody as a person of great consequence . I had just recognised one of the waiters as an old friend of mine . I introduced him to you as the Archduke Sebastian of Pomerania .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: What ! Then ...?

div.stage: She is at a loss for words . SERLO goes into a shout of laughter .

sp.speaker: SERLO . }
sp.p: } What a sell ! By George , what } a sell ! } } MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS . } } These fourGoing up to JACK STRAW .Do } speeches are said you mean to say you ’ re not .... } very quickly , } almost VINCENT . } simultaneously . } I thought I knew his face the } moment I saw him . } } MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS . } } Speak , man , speak . }

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: With the greatest urbanity .Madam , I stepped out of the uniform of a waiter at the Grand Babylon Hotel into the sober garb of the person you now see before you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Then you ’ re nothing short of an impostor . Oh ! Oh ! Now , then , Jennings , you ’ re a man . Do something .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: And he ’ s been lappin ’ up my best champagne lunch and dinner for a week .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , damn your champagne .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Mater !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , you fool , you fool ! You ’ ve ’ ad the education . You ’ ve been to Oxford , and we gave you four thousand a year . Didn ’ t you learn enough to tell the difference between an archduke and a waiter ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Serlo didn ’ t spot him .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Who ’ s Serlo ? Fine marquess he is — spends all his time with stable boys and barmaids . How do I know he is a marquess ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Don ’ t mind me , will you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Is there no one who can do something ? And that man stands there as if he didn ’ t care a ball of worsted . Don ’ t you be too sure , my young friend . It ’ s your Royal ’ Ighness this , and your Royal ’ Ighness that . And we had to call you sir . Waiter , ’ alf a pint of bitter , and look sharp about it .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Mother !

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , don ’ t talk to me .To JACK STRAW .Well , what have you got to say ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: My dear lady , you ’ re so voluble , it would be difficult for me to get a word in edgeways .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well , I ’ m listening .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Ah , there you have me , for in point of fact I can think of no appropriate observation .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: And you ’ ve been laughing at me all the time , ’ ave you ? Well , you ’ re going to laugh on the other side of your face now , young feller-my-lad .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I shall be interested to see how one performs that very curious operation .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well , shall I tell you who ’ ll show you ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Yes , do .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: The police , my lad , the police .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I wouldn ’ t send for them if I were you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Wouldn ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I wouldn ’ t really .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well , I would .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Don ’ t you think it ’ ll be a little awkward with all these people here ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: We can ’ t have a scene now , mater .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: D ’ you mean to say I ’ ve got to sit still and lump it ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: If you ask my advice , that is what I should recommend .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: All the county ’ s here , Maria . Crème de la crème .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , I wish they were all dead . I know why they come here . D ’ you think I don ’ t know that they call me a vulgar old woman behind my back ? But they come all the same because I ’ ve got two millions of money . I ’ m so rich that they can ’ t ’ elp coming .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You know , I don ’ t want to seem stuck up , but in point of fact they ’ ve come to-day to meet me . Don ’ t you think I ’ d better go and make myself amiable to them ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: You don ’ t mean to say you ’ re going back to them ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: ’ Ave I got to introduce you to the duchess ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I ’ m afraid she ’ ll make a point of it . Even duchesses have a weakness for royal personages .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: If she ever finds out !

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: The situation is not without an element of humour .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well , upon my soul , you ’ ave got a cheek !

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: The motto on my coat of arms is audacity . Only we put it in Latin because it sounds better .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Your coat of arms , I like that .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: My dear fellow , I have no doubt it is as authentic as yours .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: And do you mean to say I ’ ve got to pretend I don ’ t know anything ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I think it ’ s the only thing to do .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I can never do it . I shall never ’ old up my ’ ead again .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Come . I am convinced that the duchess is growing restive . I will murmur a few soft nothings in her ear .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , well , I suppose the only thing is to risk it . But you just wait , young man , you wait .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I think I can promise you that no one here will — blow the gaff .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Upon my soul , you talk as if I was the criminal .

div.stage: She starts and stops suddenly with a cry .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: What ’ s the matter ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , it give me such a turn . What ’ s to be done now ? The Count .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: How d ’ you mean ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I ’ d forgotten all about him . Count von Bremer coming .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Who the deuce is he ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: He ’ s your ambassador .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Of course , how stupid of me !

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: With a little scornful smile .But he won ’ t come .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Don ’ t you make too sure about that . He ’ s coming right enough . The British aristocracy was quite willing to ’ ob-nob with the Parker-Jennings , but this duty foreigner wouldn ’ t be seen in the same street with us . And you all sniggered up your sleeves , because you thought you was getting a bit of your own back . But I ’ ve got ’ im to-day , and I was going to fling him in your faces . I wrote ’ im a personal letter — as if I ’ d known him all my life — and said ....

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: And said ’ is Royal ’ Ighness particularly wished him to come . I sent the letter by one of the footmen this morning .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: By Jove !

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Well , they mustn ’ t meet . You must say that the Archduke has been seized with sudden indisposition .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Every one knows he was quite well half an hour ago .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Besides , Count von Bremer would probably insist on seeing him . It must have come as a great surprise that the Archduke Sebastian had turned up .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: My dear people , don ’ t put yourselves out . If Count von Bremer has come here to see me , it would be manifestly most discourteous to rob him of that pleasure .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I think you ’ re quite mad , Jack .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Unless I ’ m greatly mistaken , Count von Bremer has excessively bad sight .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: You don ’ t mean to say you ’ re going to meet ’ im face to face ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Remember that there are eighty-one Archdukes in Pomerania .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You told me seventy-nine a little while ago .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I have since seen in the paper that the Archduchess Anastasia has had twins , which makes eighty-one . What more probable than that the Ambassador has never seen the Archduke Sebastian ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , but what a risk to take . It ’ s enough to turn my false ’ air grey .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: In any case , he can ’ t have set eyes on him for four years , because nobody has .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I suppose it ’ asn ’ t struck you that he may talk to you in Pomeranian .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Have you ever met a waiter who couldn ’ t discourse fluently in seven languages at least ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Does that mean you can talk the Count ’ s beastly language ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Like a beastly native , madam . But I may suggest to you that there will be no need , since if I address the Count in English it would be the height of discourtesy for him to answer in any other tongue .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well , of all the cheek I ’ ve ever come across in my life , you just about take the cake .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: But look here , I remember seeing the Archduke described as a very handsome man .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Spare my blushes , dear friend . We are as like as two peas .

lg.l: MRS. WITHERS .
Maria , the Count is looking for you everywhere .
Oh , I beg your pardon , sir .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Not at all .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: He ’ s just coming along with Mr. Withers .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: In an aside to JACK STRAW .Try and behave like a gentleman .

div.stage: Enter COUNT ADRIAN VON BREMER and WITHERS .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: My dear Count !

sp.speaker: COUNT
sp.p: This is a welcome surprise , sir .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You know my hostess ?

sp.speaker: COUNT
sp.p: Shaking hands with MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS .How do you do ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It is many years since we met .

sp.speaker: COUNT
sp.p: I should have never recognised you , sir .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I expect I had a moustache when you last saw me .

sp.speaker: COUNT
sp.p: That changes a face so much . And then I am so blind nowadays .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I daresay you have later news of the Emperor than I .

lg.l: It will be a great pleasure to His Majesty to know that you are in
England , sir . I have ventured to telegraph to him .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Have you , by Jove !

sp.speaker: COUNT
sp.p: It was my duty to do so .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I daresay you have several things you want to talk to me about ?

sp.speaker: COUNT
sp.p: I was hoping you would give me a few minutes conversation .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: To MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS .Will you forgive us if we take a little stroll in the rose garden ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Grimly .I am much honoured , sir , that your Royal Highness should condescend to walk in my rose garden .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Come .He takes the COUNT ’ S arm . At the door the COUNT hesitates .Motioning to him to go first .No , I pray you . I am at home here — the most comfortable , hospitable home I have known for many a long day .

sp.speaker: COUNT
sp.p: Do you propose to stay in these parts much longer , sir ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I shall stay till Mrs. Parker-Jennings turns me out .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: You do us a great honour , sir .The COUNT goes out . Just as he is going JACK STRAW turns round and gives MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS an elaborate wink .Furiously .You , you , you , you , damned waiter !

div.stage: END OF THE SECOND ACT .

div.head: THE THIRD ACT

stage.stage: The = Scene = is the same as in the preceding ACT .

sp.speaker: Next morning
sp.p: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS and VINCENT are discovered .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Where ’ s the governor ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: He ’ s ’ aving an interview with the waiter .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: I hope he ’ ll give him what for .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: You trust your father for that . Oh , I thought I should never get through last night . Eighteen people to dinner , and me on pins and needles the whole time .

lg.l: There ’ s a ripping long account of the Garden Party in the Cheshire
Times .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Do you think I ’ ve not seen it ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: It went off beautifully ; no one can deny that . There wasn ’ t a hitch .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: With a little cry of rage .Oh !

div.stage: Enter MR. PARKER-JENNINGS .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Apologetically .My dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Indignantly .You ’ ve been and gone and made another old fool of yourself , Jennings .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: With a deprecating laugh .I ’ m afraid it ’ s the same old fool as usual , Maria .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Don ’ t make jokes at me , Robert . Keep them for your City friends .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: He ’ s had breakfast .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: ’ As he indeed . At ’ alf-past eleven . He ’ s not putting himself out , is he ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: When ’ s he going , father ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: It isn ’ t a question of when he ’ s going . Your father went to him and said he was to clear out before twelve o ’ clock or we ’ d send for the police , come what might . That ’ s what you told him , Robert , isn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well , my dear ....

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: You always were a fool , Jennings . What have you done now ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well , my dear , he insisted on having one of the footmen in the room . He said he didn ’ t like this English habit of ours of having no servants at the breakfast-table .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: You don ’ t mean to say you let him order my servants about ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: My dear , what could I do ? There was one of them in the room at the time .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: And you sat by while he ate his breakfast ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: He has a very healthy appetite , Maria .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Don ’ t talk to me . You must ’ ave ’ ad some opportunity to give him a piece of your mind .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well , my dear , we were left alone for a minute .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Helplessly .He was so affable that ....

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Affable ! Oh , you blithering fool . Wait till I get a word with him .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well , my dear , why didn ’ t you get rid of him last night ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: How could I get rid of ’ im last night , with eighteen people come to dinner to meet ’ im ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: What about Lady Wanley ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , I never want to set eyes on her again . I know she was at the bottom of this .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: But I thought you ’ d sent for her .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: So I ’ ave , and for Holland too . They got us into the mess , and they must get us out of it . It ’ s just as bad for them as for us now . That ’ s one comfort . JACK STRAW comes in , in flannels , looking very cool and comfortable .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Hulloa , there you are ! I was just hunting around for some one to give me a cigarette .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Ironically .I ’ ope you ’ ad a comfortable breakfast .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: A 1 , thanks . Give me a cigarette , old man ?

div.stage: VINCENT is helping himself to one , and JACK STRAW takes the case out of his hand , helps himself , and returns it .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Don ’ t mind me , will you ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Not at all .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Aggressively .Well ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Jolly party you gave yesterday , Mrs. Jennings . It was a great success , wasn ’ t it ?Turning to PARKER-JENNINGS .By the way , what was that port we drank last night ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: No , you don ’ t , my friend . You may be able to bluff Jennings , but you don ’ t bluff me .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Bluff ? Bluff ? I flatter myself on my knowledge of English , but I don ’ t think I ’ ve ever come across that word .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Haven ’ t you ? Perhaps you ’ aven ’ t come across the word skilly either ? But , unless you look out , you ’ ll know what it is before you want to .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You talk in riddles , dear lady . I always think it a fatiguing habit .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , I ’ ll make myself clear . Don ’ t you ’ ave any fear about that .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Sitting down lazily .I can ’ t help feeling the interval between breakfast and luncheon in a country house is one of the most agreeable moments of the day .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: See that there ’ s no one about , Vincent .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: It ’ s all right , mater .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Looking at him blandly .You have all the airs of a conspirator in a romantic play , my friend . You only want a false beard and some blue spectacles to make the picture perfect .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Now then , you listen to me , young man .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You flatter me , madam .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: We ’ ve talked it over , my ’ usband and me , and we ’ re no fools , whatever you may think . You richly deserve to be ’ anded over to the police .

lg.l: One moment . To which character are you now addressing yourself , to the
Archduke Sebastian or the waiter from the Grand Babylon Hotel ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , if you don ’ t take care , I ’ ll give you such a box on the ears .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You certainly wouldn ’ t do that to a royal personage , would you ? You must be concerned for the moment with Jack Straw .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: It may surprise you , but I ’ ave been for the last ’ alf hour .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I thought your manner had been a little abrupt .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I was saying that you richly deserved to be ’ anded over to the police .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: There may be two opinions on that question , but we will let it pass .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: But we don ’ t want a scandal .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: One has to be so careful in the smart set , doesn ’ t one ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: And we ’ re willing to let you go . Your luggage shall be packed , the motor shall take you to the station .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Mother , we shall all have to see him off , or it ’ ll look so fishy .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , we ’ ll see him off . Anything to get rid of ’ im safely . There ’ s a train in an hour from now . And I ’ ave only one piece of advice to you , and that is , take the chance while you ’ ve got it .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It ’ s very kind of you , but I ’ m extremely comfortable here .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: You make me laugh .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I always think it hard that it should be so difficult to make people do that when you ’ re trying to be funny , and so easy when you ’ re trying to be serious .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: You don ’ t want me to tell my footman to take you by the scruff of the neck , and ....

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: My dear lady , let us keep perfectly calm . It would become neither of us to lose our tempers .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Do you mean to say you won ’ t go ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You put it in such a brutal way . Let us say rather , that I cannot tear myself away from your hospitable roof .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Ha , and how long do you propose to give us the honour of your company ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Well , I really haven ’ t quite made up my mind . I ’ m proposing to await developments .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Send for the police , Robert . I won ’ t put up with it .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: You know , mother ....

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Hold your tongue , Vincent ....To JACK STRAW .Oh , my friend , I ’ m sorry for you . Those nice white ’ ands of yours will look pretty after they ’ ve been picking oakum for six months .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I had an idea that had been abolished in England .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh no , I think not .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Ah , perhaps it was the treadmill I was thinking of .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well , Vincent , ’ ow much longer are you going to stand there like a stuffed owl ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Do my eyes deceive me , or is that a local paper that I see ?He takes it up .Ah , I surmised that it would have an account of your garden party . Two columns of it , by Jove ! You must wish you hadn ’ t asked so many people .Reading .The Duchess of St. Erth , the Marchioness of Mereston , the Marquess of Mereston , Lord and Lady Hollington , Viscount Parnaby — dear me , how smart — Lady Wanley , Mr. and Mrs. Lamberville , the Bishop of Sheffield , and the Honourable Mrs. Spratte .... I say , won ’ t your humbler friends grind their teeth with envy . But doesn ’ t it say anything about me ? Here it is .Reading .“ The Archduke Sebastian looked every inch a prince .” I said so .Reading to himself .Oh , spare my blushes .Aloud .“ His Royal Highness enchanted every one by the grace of his bearing and the charm of his Imperial personality .” Blood will tell .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: To PARKER-JENNINGS .Are you going to stand there and let this man insult me , Robert ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Blandly .And what do you imagine all these noble and distinguished persons will think when they read in the next number of the local paper that the royal personage whose hand they were so pleased to shake — I did my duty like a hero , didn ’ t I ?— was serving coffee and liqueurs a fortnight ago in the Grand Babylon Hotel ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , be quiet , you ....

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I can hear a titter rising softly in the village , with the doctor and the parson and the solicitor , whom you didn ’ t ask to your party , and I can hear it increase to a ripple of laughter as the story spreads through Cheshire . I can hear a Homeric peal as it travels from county to county . It ’ s a great guffaw in Manchester and Liverpool and the cities of the North , and already I hear the deep laughter of Bristol and Portsmouth and the West . And when it reaches London — you know how things go in London , it ’ s so large that it takes it a little time really to get hold of anything , but when at last it comes , can ’ t you see the huge city holding its aching sides and bellowing with laughter . But I ’ ll tell you who won ’ t see the joke —taking up the paper and reading— oh , they ’ ll laugh very much on the wrong side of their mouths ; the Duchess of St. Erth , the Marchioness of Mereston , and my Lady Hollington and my Lord Parnaby , and the Bishop of Sheffield and the Honourable Mrs. Spratte .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , you devil !

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I can see you flying before the laughter like three tremulous leaves before the wind , and the laughter will pursue you to Paris , where they ’ ll make little songs about you on the boulevards , and the Riviera , where they ’ ll sell your photographs on picture postcards . I can see you fleeing across the Atlantic to hide your heads in the immensity of America , and there the Yellow Press , pea-green with frenzy , will pile column of ridicule upon column of invective . Oh , my dear lady , do you think it isn ’ t worth while to endure six months hard labour to amuse the world so profoundly ?

div.stage: There is a silence . PARKER-JENNINGS takes out his handkerchief , makes it into a ball and mops his forehead . VINCENT , noticing him , does the same . MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS gives the two a glance , sees what they are doing , takes out her handkerchief , rolls it up into a ball , and slowly mops her forehead .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: It ’ s no good , Maria ; we can ’ t give him in charge .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Tell me something I don ’ t know . We ’ re in the man ’ s hands , and he knows it .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: With an amiable smile .I thought you would come to see the situation from my point of view .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Beaten .What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: At the present moment , with your permission , I am going to have a small brandy and soda . Ring the bell , Vincent .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Shall I , ma ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: With angry resignation .Oh , yes , ring it .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: For your own sake , I warn you to behave with the utmost decorum before the servant .

div.stage: A FOOTMAN appears .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Bring his Royal Highness a brandy and soda , James .

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Very good , sir .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , I wish it would choke you .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I ’ m afraid I can hold out no hope of that .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Now , look here , I ’ m no fool , Mr. —— I don ’ t know what to call you ....

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You ’ ll find it ’ ll be more convenient to address me as you have always done .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: The cheek of it ! I can see myself saying sir to a damned waiter .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You were assuring me that you were no fool madam .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: You know just as well as we do that the last thing we want is a scandal , and you ’ ve got us on toast .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Well browned on both sides .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: If you ’ ll go quietly and at once we ’ ll give you a couple of hundred pounds . There !

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Oh , this is a blow . To think that any one should be willing to give two hundred pounds to get rid of me ! And I ’ ve always flattered myself that I was such an agreeable guest in a country house .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: They have funny tastes in the servants ’ hall , I daresay .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You have quite a knack of saying clever things , haven ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Madam , nothing will induce me to leave you till I have eradicated the unfortunate impression which I appear to have made on you .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Do you mean to say ....

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Interrupting .Take care , mother . There ’ s James . The FOOTMAN enters with brandy and soda and glasses .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Be a good fellow , Vincent , and mix it for me , will you ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Certainly , sir .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Where do you get your brandy , Mr. Jennings ? I like it very much .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: It ’ s very good of your Royal Highness to say so .

div.stage: Exit FOOTMAN .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , it ’ s insufferable .

div.stage: Enter the FOOTMAN to announce .

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: Lady Wanley . Mr. Holland .

div.stage: They enter . Exit FOOTMAN .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: There you are at last ! This is a pretty kettle of fish .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Mother , for heaven ’ s sake don ’ t be vulgar .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , I can ’ t be refined now . If I ’ m vulgar , I can ’ t ’ elp it .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: But what is the matter ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Good heavens , he ’ s the matter . He won ’ t go .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You know , it makes me feel very uncomfortable to hear you discussing me like this . Wouldn ’ t you like me to retire ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: We ’ ve threatened him with the police .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: He just laughs at us .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: We ’ ve even demeaned ourselves by offering him money .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Of course he doesn ’ t want your money .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well , ’ adn ’ t you better suggest what he does want ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Look here , Jack , you ’ ve made fools of the whole lot of us . Won ’ t you be a brick and clear out ? We really are in a deuce of a scrape .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I am always touched by an appeal to my better nature , but in this case I propose to steel myself against your entreaties .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Damn you !

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Don ’ t lose your temper . You ’ ll only say something foolish , and I shall score off you .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: There ’ s only one thing to do , and that is to turn you out by main force .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: That , strange as it may seem to you , has already been suggested , but I have explained to dear Mrs. Jennings the inconvenience of that course .

div.stage: Enter the FOOTMAN .

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: Mrs. Withers is in her motor , madam , and wishes to know if you can see her for a moment .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , I can see nobody .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I hope you ’ re not refusing to see her on my account , dear Mrs. Jennings .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Very affably , before the servant .Oh no , sir .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I wonder if you ’ d very much mind her coming in . I thought her such a nice woman , I should like to see her again .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , of course , if your Royal Highness wishes it ....

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Thanks so much .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Show ’ er in , James .

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: Very good , madam .

div.stage: Exit FOOTMAN .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: My own ’ ouse isn ’ t my own now . I ’ m forced to see every one I don ’ t want to . If there ’ s any one I can ’ t bear it ’ s Fanny Withers . I only asked her yesterday because I thought she ’ d eat her ’ eart out with jealousy . She ’ s a snob if you like . I don ’ t know what she wants to come here for at this hour .To JACK STRAW .Impostor ! Impostor !

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You know , upon my word you ’ re all very ungrateful . I lent an éclat to your party which has found lasting fame in the columns of the local paper . I chatted cordially with the Duchess of St. Erth , I allowed the Bishop of Sheffield to tell me harrowing stories about the immorality of the very best people , and when Count what ’ s his name ....

lg.l: Adrian von Bremer — you might trouble to remember the name of your own
Ambassador .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: And when Count von Bremer came on the scene , and you were all at your wits ’ end , I carried the whole thing off in a way which only my native modesty prevents me from describing as superb .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: How he didn ’ t find you out I don ’ t know . I was on pins and needles all the time he was here .

div.stage: Enter the FOOTMAN , followed by MRS. WITHERS .

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: Mrs. Horton Withers .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: Oh , my dear , I had to pop in just to tell you how beautifully everything went off yesterday .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I ’ m glad our party had your approval .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: How do you do , Mrs. Withers ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: It ’ s very good of your Royal Highness to remember me .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It ’ s one of the specialities of my profession , you know .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: Are you going to favour us much longer with your presence in the neighbourhood , sir ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: If Mrs. Jennings will keep me I don ’ t propose to make an immediate move .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: My house is at your disposal , sir , as long as you choose to honour it .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Mrs. Jennings is the most amiable hostess . Don ’ t you think it would be nice if we took a turn in the garden , Mrs. Jennings ? I ’ m sure Lady Wanley would like you to show her your roses .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Mrs. Jennings was good enough to show them to us yesterday .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: We have it on good authority that a thing of beauty is a joy for ever . Mr. Jennings will show them to you again to-day .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I shall be very proud and ’ appy to carry out your Royal Highness ’ s wishes .

div.stage: JACK STRAW stands at the door for LADY WANLEY and PARKER-JENNINGS to go out .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: To VINCENT .Won ’ t you come ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Certainly , sir .

div.stage: MRS. WITHERS and VINCENT go out .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I will join you in one moment . By the way , where is your daughter ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: She ’ s gone for a walk with Lord Serlo .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Be so good as to tell her the moment she comes in that I should be very grateful if I could see her .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: What about ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: She ’ ll doubtless be able to tell you that herself after our interview .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I ’ m not going to do anything of the kind .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You will be so good as to do what I ask , Mrs. Jennings .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: There , you see he actually orders me about now . I ’ m beginning to think we shall never get rid of him . I feel that he ’ ll stay on here always . I can see him growing old under this roof , eating my food and drinking my wine , and sending in his tailor ’ s bills for Jennings to pay . And it ’ s all your doing .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I ’ m very sorry . I promise you that .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: What ’ s the good of being sorry ? The only thing you can do is to ’ elp us to get rid of ’ im . And it ’ s ruined Ethel ’ s chances with Serlo . He won ’ t look at her now .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Well , I daresay that ’ s not much loss .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I ’ m only thankful she wouldn ’ t ’ ave anything to do with that man when we thought ’ e was an Archduke .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Do you know , if I were you I ’ d let her see him . I have an idea that when he ’ s had a talk with her he ’ ll be quite willing to go .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: What do you mean by that ?

div.stage: Enter ETHEL and LORD SERLO .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Very affably .Has Ethel been taking you for a walk , dear Lord Serlo ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Yes , we ’ ve been for a little stroll , don ’ t you know .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I do ’ ope she ’ asn ’ t tired you . She ’ s such a walker , ain ’ t you , my dear ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: My idea of goin ’ for a walk is sitting on a gate , don ’ t you know .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: And a very good idea too . That ’ s just what I like myself .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Drily .Change in the wind to-day , isn ’ t there ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Innocently .Is there ? I didn ’ t notice it .

div.stage: PARKER-JENNINGS comes in frantically .

lg.l: Maria , he ’ s cutting all our prize roses for the show and giving them to
Fannie Withers .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh !

div.stage: She is just going to bolt out when JACK STRAW appears with a handful of magnificent roses .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I say , you haven ’ t got a basket , have you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: You — you — you perfect fool !

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: What have I done now ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: We were going to show those next week at the Crystal Palace .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I thought they were very nice . That ’ s why it struck me Mrs. Withers might like them .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Snatching them from him .Oh !

div.stage: She flounces out , followed by PARKER-JENNINGS .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Coming into the room calmly .I ’ m afraid I haven ’ t done the right thing .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: You ’ ve put your foot right in it this time , old man .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I wish I had that little book of etiquette on me . I wonder if it says anything about prize roses .To Ethel .I haven ’ t had the pleasure of saying good-morning to you yet .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: You know , old man , I don ’ t want to seem disagreeable , but when Miss Jennings and I went for a walk we had some sort of idea that by the time we came back you ’ d have hooked it , don ’ t you know .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: My dear Holland , I wonder if you ’ d do me the service of telling Mrs. Withers that dear Mrs. Jennings is putting the roses into a basket for her .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Laughing against his will .It ’ s not the least use being angry with you , Jack . I ’ ll go by all means .

div.stage: Exit .

lg.l: There goes a man of tact . If I were a Sultan I ’ d make him my Grand
Vizier .

div.stage: He looks reflectively , but very pointedly , at SERLO .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: What are you starin ’ at me for ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I was wondering how I could suggest to you with proper delicacy that you might conveniently follow his example .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I should much prefer Lord Serlo to stay here .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I have matters of some importance to discuss with you .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I am sure that you have nothing to say that Lord Serlo cannot hear .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Very well , I will make an effort to overcome my customary modesty .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: I don ’ t know where that comes in . You ’ ve got about the biggest cheek that I ’ ve ever come across .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: To tell you the truth , it has been my only means of livelihood for the last four years .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: What have you to say to me ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Couldn ’ t you give me a slight smile just to encourage me a little ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You force me to say what I would rather have left unsaid . I ’ m horrified that you should be so hatefully cruel . I think it ’ s infamous that you should lend yourself to a stupid practical joke .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: My dear Serlo , won ’ t you — hook it ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I want him to stay .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: It makes him feel very uncomfortable . He ’ s full of tact too — I ’ ll make him a grand vizier — and he ’ s feeling awfully de trop .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: You needn ’ t bother about my feelings so much as all that , you know .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: To Ethel .Won ’ t you hear what I ’ ve got to say for myself ? You don ’ t think I care twopence about their practical joke ? I came here because it was my only chance of seeing you .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: What you ’ ve done fills me with horror and disgust .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Didn ’ t you see from the first minute that I was desperately in love with you ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: I say , this really is very awkward for me .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You told me not to bother about your feelings .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Unable to prevent a laugh .You know , you ’ re too absurd . I know I ought to be very angry with you , but I can ’ t .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Do you remember what you said to me yesterday ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Then I ’ ll remind you . You asked me to go away — because I was a royal personage . Do you still want me to go if I ’ m only a waiter ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I might have known that you were laughing at me all the time .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: You know , if I had been a royal personage and disguised myself as a waiter in order to be by your side you ’ d have thought it very romantic . Why should it shock you when it is a waiter who for the same reason assumes the royal personage ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: If you can ’ t see the difference it ’ s useless for me to tell you .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Won ’ t you marry me , Ethel ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: I say , I ’ ve got a good mind to kick you out of the house .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Have you ? In that case I can only congratulate myself that I ’ m the champion amateur boxer in Pomerania .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: That complicates matters a bit , don ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Upon my soul , I ’ ve never made a proposal of marriage under such embarrassing circumstances .To ETHEL .Now , my dear , don ’ t be unreasonable . You practically refused me yesterday because I was an Archduke . You ’ re not going to refuse me now because I ’ m nobody in particular ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Frigidly .And can you give me any reason why I should accept you ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Well , it may have escaped your notice , but there ’ s the very good reason that you ’ re just as much in love with me as I am with you .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Can you honestly deny it ? But if you do I shall venture to disbelieve you .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: It ’ s very easy to convince you . Lord Serlo , you were good enough to tell me yesterday that ....

div.stage: She stops with a little tremor of hesitation .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: By Jove , d ’ you mean it ?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Smiling .I mean anything you like .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: With a low bow .Mr . Straw , I beg to announce to you my engagement with Miss Ethel Parker-Jennings .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I ’ m still unconvinced . I ’ m afraid you ’ re incorrigibly romantic , my dear , and I ’ m certain your mamma will be very much annoyed .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Oh , you are too exasperating . I wish I could make you really angry . HOLLAND runs in .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: I say , Jack , look out .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: What ’ s the matter ?

div.stage: Enter MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS , much agitated , and PARKER-JENNINGS .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: The game ’ s up . It ’ s too late now to do anything .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Von Bremer has come again .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: And he ’ s got some one with him in his motor , who looks suspiciously like a policeman in plain clothes .

lg.l: What ’ s to be done ? For ’ eaven ’ s sake , don ’ t stand there grinning like a
Cheshire cat .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Quickly .You won ’ t be arrested ?

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: Look here , there ’ s still time for you to get out .

div.stage: Enter VINCENT .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: Lady Wanley ’ s talking to him . She ’ ll detain him as long as she can .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Blessings on her ! I ’ ll forgive ’ er everything .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Oh , please go while you have a chance . I couldn ’ t bear to see you arrested .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Why should you care ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Now , look here . You ’ ve played a nasty trick on me , but you ’ ve got the cheek of the devil . I don ’ t want you to get into trouble . I don ’ t know what there is about you , but I can ’ t ’ elp liking you .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Madam , only the importunate presence of your lord and master prevents me from hurling myself at your feet .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , don ’ t talk stuff . I want to ’ elp you to get away .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: With a dramatic gesture .Madam , my mother ’ s only son has never fled before a foe . I will stay and face the music .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I ’ m not thinking of myself now . If there is a scandal I ’ m rich enough to make people forget it .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: I say , old man , you ’ d better hook it . England ’ s no place for you just now .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: In an undertone .If you care for me at all , don ’ t run this horrible risk .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: If you were only pressing me to stay this unanimity would be extremely flattering .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: The man ’ s mad . The man ’ s as mad as a March ’ are . He ought to be shut up in a lunatic asylum .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I forget if Napoleon was one of my ancestors , but I feel just like him at this moment . “ J ’ y suis , j ’ y reste .”

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: In point of fact it was MacMahon who said that .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: With a noble flourish .I prefer to think it was Napoleon .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: They ’ re just strolling along .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Then it ’ s too late . And it ’ s all got to come out before Florrie Withers .

sp.speaker: VINCENT
sp.p: From the window .I say , Lady Wanley is making him look at the roses .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: She is a brick ; she ’ s gaining every moment she can .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: By the way , talking about roses , have you had that bunch put in a basket that I cut for Mrs. Withers ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , I should like to take you by the neck and strangle you .

sp.speaker: PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Look out .

div.stage: They all stop for a moment in a state of breathless expectation . LADY WANLEY comes in with MRS. WITHERS . She gasps as she sees JACK STRAW .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: Oh , I thought you ’ d gone .

div.stage: She is immediately followed by ADRIAN VON BREMER . JACK STRAW goes up to him very cordially .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Ah , my dear friend , I ’ ve been expecting you all the morning .

div.stage: They all start . As the scene proceeds there is in every one increasing astonishment and perplexity .

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: I couldn ’ t come before . I have only just received the answer to my telegram .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Have you good news for me ?

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: The best . The Emperor agrees to all your wishes .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Bless his old head .

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: His Majesty is all eagerness to see you again . He is expecting a letter from you by every post .He goes up to ETHEL .Madam , I am commanded by my august master to offer you his most cordial greeting .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I don ’ t know if I ’ m standing on my ’ ead or my ’ eels .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Then nothing remains but for me to make my declaration in due form . Mrs. Jennings , I have my grandfather ’ s permission to ask you for your daughter ’ s hand in marriage .

lg.l: But the man ’ s an impostor . He ’ s no more the Archduke
Sebastian than I am .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Oh , well , if you like you can ’ ave it . You were there when it all started . I suppose I got out the wrong side of bed that morning , and when Mrs. Thing-a-magig , the Vicar ’ s wife , come up to me at the Grand Babylon Hotel , I snubbed her . I ’ ve been very sorry for it since , and I ’ ve been punished for it . They knew I was an old snob — like you , Florrie — they thought they ’ d pay me out . They got one of the waiters from the ’ otel to dress up like a gentleman , and they introduced him as the Archduke Sebastian .

sp.speaker: MRS. WITHERS
sp.p: Pointing to JACK STRAW .That ?

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Yes , that ! He ’ s a waiter , that ’ s what he is . And for the last week I ’ ve been making a perfect fool of myself over ’ im .

lg.l: But — I don ’ t understand . I ’ ve known the Archduke
Sebastian since he was born .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: You ’ re mistaken . This person and I were in America together . I lived with him for two years . I don ’ t know his real name , but he passes under that of Jack Straw .

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: But what you say is absurd . I know him as well as my own son .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: D ’ you mean to say he really is an Archduke ?

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: Of course he is . The only mystery is how he turned up here when we ’ ve been hunting the whole world for the last four years to find him .

sp.speaker: HOLLAND
sp.p: But are you the Jack Straw who was with me in the States ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LADY WANLEY
sp.p: And are you the waiter of the Grand Babylon Hotel ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: And are you the Archduke Sebastian of Pomerania ?

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Well , I ’ m jiggered .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Perhaps you will allow me to explain . Four years ago I fell desperately in love with a lady whose speciality it was to kick higher than any one else in the world . She could kick a man ’ s tall hat off his head with such grace that I asked her to marry me . My grandfather refused to consent , and the lady was hurried over the frontier .With a glance at ETHEL .I was a romantic dog myself in those days , and I followed her , only to find that she had already three more or less lawful husbands . The sight of them , and the conviction that her peculiar talent would not greatly add to the felicity of domestic life , cured me of my passion . But the world did seem a bit hollow and empty , and I thought I ’ d see how it looked from the point of view of a man who had nothing but his wits to live on . After trying it , I tell you frankly that I much prefer living on the revenues which rise from the strength of arm of my ancestors . When you saw me at the Grand Babylon Hotel I was preparing to return to the bosom of my family , but I saw this young lady , and the chance offering , decided to come down here . It was not unnatural that when I was asked to assume a grandiloquent name I should assume my own . Yesterday , when I met Count von Bremer , I begged him to wire to the Emperor , asking for his consent to my marriage with Miss Ethel Jennings .

sp.speaker: VON BREMER
sp.p: I have only to add that the Emperor , delighted with the prospect of seeing once more his favourite grandson , has gladly given his consent .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: And when I think of all the things I ’ ve called you these last few hours ....

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: They went in at the ear of a waiter , Madam , and slipped out at that of an Archduke .

div.stage: He goes up to ETHEL .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: And now it only rests with you to give peace to an aged Emperor , satisfaction to eighty-one Archdukes , and happiness to your unworthy servant .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I am engaged to be married to Lord Serlo .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: What ! I know nothing about this .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: I knew our mamma wouldn ’ t be pleased .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: The fact remains .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Going to SERLO .Now , my dear friend , you ’ ve got the chance of a lifetime . It ’ s quite clear to me that there ’ s only one course open to you . Take the centre of the stage and renounce the lady with all the moving expressions you can think of .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Look here , old man , I don ’ t think I quite like the way you keep on pulling my leg .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Put a little dignity into it , man .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: I may be a blithering ass , but I can see without your tellin ’ me that Ethel wouldn ’ t have had me at any price if she hadn ’ t wanted to score off you .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Oh , how some men throw away their chances ! Strike the pathetic note , old man , or you ’ re done . When you ’ ve finished there oughtn ’ t to be a dry eye in the place .

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Well , the fact is — it had entirely slipped my memory at the moment , but I had a letter this morning from the lady ’ s solicitor to remind me — I happen to be engaged to a young woman who can kick a man ’ s topper off too .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: By Jove , I wonder if it ’ s the same one .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Why didn ’ t you tell me ?

sp.speaker: SERLO
sp.p: Well , you know , it was a bit awk when you — er ....

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Threw yourself at his head .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: To Jack Straw with a smile .I ought to be very angry with you . You ’ ve laughed at me all the time . I don ’ t believe you ’ ll ever take me seriously . If I really were the romantic creature you say I am , I ’ d be very dignified and refuse to have anything to do with you at all .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: But like all women you ’ re very sensible at heart , and you ’ ll do nothing of the kind .

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: It ’ s not because I ’ m sensible , but because I suppose you were quite right in what you said just now .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: Bless you ! I ’ d throw myself down on the floor and implore you to walk on me only I ’ m convinced you ’ d take me at my word .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: With enormous satisfaction .I knew he was an Archduke all the time . You can ’ t deceive a mother .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: With a start .There ’ s one thing I must break to you at once . Pomerania is in some ways still a barbarous country . We have a dreadful law that when a member of the royal family marries a foreigner not of royal blood , his wife ’ s relations are prohibited from entering it .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: I should like to see any one prohibit me from going to see my own daughter .

sp.speaker: JACK STRAW
sp.p: My dear lady , it grieves me infinitely to say it , but no sooner had you crossed our frontier than you would be instantly beheaded .

sp.speaker: MRS. PARKER-JENNINGS
sp.p: Truly , sir , a barbarous country .
